questions.text: A newborn boy is born at 37 weeks estimated gestational age by spontaneous vaginal delivery and appears cyanotic at the delivery. The mother did not have prenatal care. Rupture of membranes was 12 hours before delivery, group B streptococcus (GBS) is negative, and amniotic fluid is clear. APGAR scores are 4 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively, and there is minimal respiratory effort initially. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 75/min, blood pressure is 65/39 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. There is nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions are seen. No dysmorphic features are seen. Mucous membranes and the extremities are cyanotic. Cardiopulmonary exam is significant for normal heart sounds without murmurs and decreased air entry with bowel sounds heard over the left lung. The abdomen is scaphoid without hepatosplenomegaly. Femoral pulses are equal bilaterally. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient whose mother did not have prenatal care presents with central cyanosis and respiratory distress at birth. Physical exam showing scaphoid abdomen with bowel sounds in the chest is indicative of pulmonary hypoplasia from congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Chest X-ray showing bowel loops in the left hemithorax confirms this diagnosis. This newborn is unstable and in respiratory distress; therefore, intubation and mechanical ventilation are necessary to maintain airway and breathing.  

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to lung compression by abdominal viscera in the chest and is usually identified by prenatal ultrasound. Physical exam in newborns shows respiratory distress at birth, central cyanosis, low oxygen saturation, and scaphoid abdomen with audible bowel sounds in the chest. Chest X-ray will show bowel loops in the left hemithorax with displacement of the cardiac silhouette to the right.

When initially evaluating a newborn with central cyanosis, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Newborns with cyanosis are considered unstable, so maintaining the airway and breathing is essential. Delay in securing adequate airway can lead to severe acidosis and hypoxia, which increases the risk of pulmonary hypertension. Obtaining intravenous access, continuous vital signs monitoring, and oxygen supplementation as needed are the next steps in treatment.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous antibiotics  :
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics should be started in patients with suspected neonatal sepsis and neonatal pneumonia. This patient has no evidence of infection and, instead, is unstable from a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the priority. 
❌ Intravenous prostaglandins infusion :
Incorrect: Intravenous prostaglandins infusion is used in patients with cyanotic congenital heart diseases to maintain ductus arteriosus patency and systemic circulation. This patient is unstable with congenital diaphragmatic hernia; intubation with mechanical ventilation is the priority.  
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation :
Incorrect: Observation of this unstable neonate with cyanosis and respiratory distress is inappropriate and will result in worsening hypoxemia, acidosis, and increased risk for pulmonary hypertension. This patient should be intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is useful for determining the etiology of neonatal cyanosis in patients with suspected congenital heart diseases. This patient is in respiratory distress from a congenital diaphragmatic hernia; intubation with mechanical ventilation is the best next step in management.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a wellness visit. Past medical history is notable for cystic fibrosis. The patient has had several episodes of pneumonia over the past year and currently has a persistent cough with production of large quantities of viscous sputum. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for rhonchi throughout the bilateral lung fields. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with a history of cystic fibrosis and recurrent pulmonary infections was most likely prescribed N-acetylcysteine.    

N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that liquefies mucus and is often used in patients with thick secretions, such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis. This medication works by disrupting disulfide bonds within the mucosal polypeptides. N-acetylcysteine can also be administered to treat acetaminophen overdose by regenerating glutathione and is used off-label as a prophylaxis against contrast-induced nephropathy.  

N-acetylcysteine may cause an anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously and can also cause gastrointestinal side effects (e.g. nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, flatus).  

Option Analysis

❌ Dextromethorphan:
Incorrect: Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that acts by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors and additionally acts as a weak mu receptor antagonist. The medication can lead to cough suppression, which may further impair sputum clearance.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is an α-agonist that can be used as a nasal decongestant. This medication causes vasoconstriction and reduces mucosal edema. However, phenylephrine would not enhance sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds.
❌ Guaifenesin:
Incorrect: Guaifenesin is an expectorant that increases mucosal clearance. It works by stimulating the production of hydrated respiratory secretions.  
❌ Dornase alfa:
Incorrect: Dornase alfa can assist with sputum clearance in patients with cystic fibrosis. This medication works by depolymerizing DNA within sputum and reducing its viscosity.   
✅ N-acetylcysteine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of poor feeding and high-pitched crying. A caregiver reports the infant has been feeding very slowly, and if the feeding rate is increased, the infant develops a high-pitched inspiratory cough. These symptoms have been present for approximately three weeks. The infant was born full term and has not had any illnesses since birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normal tone and reflexes with occasional stridor. When placed supine on the exam table, the stridor noticeably worsens. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further testing?
questions.solution:
This 6-week-old infant presents with slow feeding and a high-pitched cry. These features are characteristic of laryngomalacia, which results from collapse of the supraglottic structures due to soft, immature laryngeal cartilage. Stridor typically occurs during inspiration and is often worsened by feeding, agitation, or the supine position. Laryngoscopy confirms the diagnosis by visualizing dynamic supraglottic collapse.         

When evaluating an infant with poor feeding, history and physical examination are essential in guiding the differential diagnosis. Physical findings may reveal craniofacial abnormalities such as cleft lip, cleft palate, or micrognathia, all of which are clinically apparent. Ankyloglossia may present with difficulty latching and is identified by a tight lingual or upper lip frenulum.         

In some cases, the physical examination may not reveal obvious abnormalities. Frothing or bubbling from the nose and mouth raises concern for esophageal atresia. Choanal atresia is often associated with cyanosis that improves with crying, whereas laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying, feeding, or changes in position. These conditions require confirmatory testing. Esophageal atresia is evaluated with plain radiography and often confirmed with endoscopy or bronchoscopy. Choanal atresia is best diagnosed with computed tomography (CT) imaging. Laryngomalacia is confirmed with flexible laryngoscopy.        

Gastroesophageal reflux disease can also present with poor feeding and is often accompanied by fussiness, regurgitation, and back arching during feeds. Diagnosis is clinical and based on response to conservative treatment.   

Option Analysis

❌ Airless scaphoid abdomen:
Incorrect: An airless scaphoid abdomen on X-ray may be seen with esophageal atresia. However, esophageal atresia typically presents in the first few days of life with excessive oral secretions, choking, and difficulty passing a nasogastric tube. This infant’s subacute, progressive symptoms are not consistent with that diagnosis.        
❌ Retained fluid in nasal cavity :
Incorrect: Choanal atresia can present with retained secretions in the nasal cavity and respiratory distress, particularly in bilateral cases. However, it usually manifests in the immediate neonatal period with cyanosis that improves with crying. This infant’s stable oxygenation and progressive stridor make choanal atresia unlikely. 
❌ Bilateral bony atresia :
Incorrect: Bilateral choanal atresia presents with cyclic cyanosis that improves with crying and respiratory distress during feeding. This infant has normal oxygenation and no signs of cyanosis, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
✅ Collapse of supraglottic structures :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thickened pylorus:
Incorrect: Pyloric stenosis presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. This infant has feeding difficulty without vomiting, making pyloric stenosis an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a past medical history of primary ciliary dyskinesia presents to the emergency department with a fever and cough for one day. This morning his parent noticed that he was working hard to breathe and brought him in for further evaluation. His parents state that he has been doing well and has had no significant infections or hospitalizations in the past year. He receives chest physiotherapy daily and is up to date on immunizations. He is at the 24<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and the 16<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On examination, he is in mild respiratory distress with tachypnea, belly breathing, and intercostal retractions. Bilateral inner ear effusions are present as are nasal congestion and polyps. No murmur is appreciated on cardiopulmonary exam. Rales are heard over the right lower lobe. The patient is started on 2L/min oxygen, IV access is achieved, and he is placed on cardiac monitoring. Chest x-ray confirms right lower lobe pneumonia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and presents with fever, cough, and increased work of breathing. Rales raise suspicion for pneumonia which is confirmed with chest x-ray. This patient is initially stabilized and placed on supplemental oxygen. Sputum culture should be sent before the initiation of empiric antibiotics to help guide antibiotic selection.

The first step in managing a patient with PCD is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment and determine if the patient is stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, necessary interventions such as obtaining IV access, placing the patient on continuous monitoring, and administering supplemental oxygen should be pursued.

Patients with PCD are at risk for bronchiectasis and recurrent respiratory tract infections, as well as sinusitis and otitis media. Common pathogens implicated in respiratory infections in patients with PCD include Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. If the patient with a respiratory infection is stable, a sputum culture should be obtained before starting empiric antibiotics. Prior sputum cultures and sensitivities should also be reviewed to help guide the choice of antibiotic therapy.

Chest physiotherapy, hypertonic saline nebulizers, and rhDNAse can be started in the hospital to assist with airway clearance. They should be started after the patient is stabilized and treatment of underlying infection with antibiotics is started. They are routinely prescribed for patients with PCD to help prevent recurrent infections.

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain sputum culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administer ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Although antibiotics for pneumonia should be started as soon as possible, a sputum culture should be obtained first to help tailor antibiotic therapy in this patient. It is also recommended to review prior sputum cultures to guide the selection of antibiotics in patients with PCD.
❌ Start chest physiotherapy:
Incorrect: Chest physiotherapy is recommended for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia; however, it should be initiated once the patient is stabilized and treatment is initiated for the underlying infection.
❌ Administer hypertonic saline nebulizer:
Incorrect: Hypertonic saline nebulizers are recommended for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia who have recurrent respiratory infections or ongoing moderate-severe respiratory symptoms, however, nebulizers should be started after the patient is stabilized, sputum cultures are obtained, and antibiotics are started.
❌ Consult pulmonology:
Incorrect: Pulmonology should be consulted for a patient with primary ciliary dyskinesia, but not before the patient is stabilized, sputum cultures are collected, and empiric antibiotics are initiated for the underlying infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to a pulmonologist for evaluation of a chronic productive cough, congestion, recurrent respiratory infections, and recurrent otitis media. Parents report the patient has been sick much more often than his peers. He was born full-term but did spend time in the NICU for respiratory distress. He is up to date on all vaccinations including influenza, COVID-19, and pneumococcal 13-valent conjugate vaccine (PCV13). He is at the 23<sup>rd</sup> percentile for height and the 12<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1 F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 106/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98%. Head and neck examination shows bilateral middle ear effusions, nasal congestion, and polyps. Heart rate is regular, and no murmur is appreciated. Diffuse rhonchi are heard without increased work of breathing. The patient undergoes a full work-up. Nitrous oxide is found to be very low, and a genetic pulmonary disease is confirmed. Which of the following interventions is recommended?

choices.text: Vitamin A, D, E, K supplementation
Yearly surveillance of liver function tests (LFTs)

questions.solution:
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with a history of neonatal respiratory distress, chronic cough, recurrent respiratory infections, and recurrent otitis media who is found to have low NO levels and a genetic pulmonary disease. Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia should be up to date on immunizations for influenza, COVID-19, and pneumococcus. If a patient has only received PCV13, they need to receive a dose of pneumococcal 20-valent conjugate vaccine (PCV20) or pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23).

Similar management strategies are used for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia and cystic fibrosis (CF). Maintaining airway clearance and preventing respiratory infections with chest physiotherapy and regular exercise for both diseases is important. Nebulized hypertonic saline and recombinant human deoxyribonuclease (rhDNase) are used in both diseases, but more often in patients with cystic fibrosis. Both types of patients should receive immunizations including PCV20 or PPSV23, influenza, and COVID-19. Respiratory infections should be treated promptly. Occasionally prophylactic Azithromycin is used in patients with recurrent bronchiectasis. If a patient is prone to Pseudomonas, nebulized tobramycin is often used.

Patients with cystic fibrosis often develop gastrointestinal symptoms and require additional nutritional and pancreatic support. This includes close monitoring of growth, pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), and oral salts. Some patients require insulin or ursodiol.

Surveillance includes chest computed tomography and routine sputum cultures in patients with PCD, chest x-rays, and regular oropharyngeal cultures in patients with CF. Due to the gastrointestinal complications seen in patients with CF, they should undergo routine screening with liver function tests and oral glucose tolerance testing.

For patients with CF and PCD, Ear, Nose, and Throat physicians (ENTs) are often consulted regarding possible tympanostomy with tube placement and nasal polypectomy. As with any genetic condition, genetic counseling should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prophylactic Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Antibiotics treat recurrent bacterial infections that often occur in patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia; however Prophylactic antibiotics are not typically prescribed.
❌ Vitamin A, D, E, K supplementation:
Incorrect: Patients with cystic fibrosis require supplements with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). This is not necessary for this patient who likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia.
❌ Yearly surveillance of liver function tests (LFTs):
Incorrect: Surveillance of LFTs is recommended for patients with cystic fibrosis. Mucous can block bile ducts preventing adequate excretion resulting in chronic inflammation and liver fibrosis. It is not typically necessary in patients with PCD.
❌ Biannual chest computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: Some providers obtain yearly chest CTs on patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia to detect early airway and structural lung changes, although there isn’t consensus on frequency. Biannual chest CTs are not routinely recommended.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of a chronic wet cough. The caregiver reports frequent episodes of nasal congestion and recurrent respiratory infections, including multiple episodes of bronchitis and two prior hospitalizations for pneumonia. There is no history of wheezing or known allergies. Growth has remained at the lower end of the normal range without significant weight loss. Newborn screening was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital clubbing is noted, and lung auscultation reveals scattered rhonchi and coarse breath sounds bilaterally. Chest X-ray shows mild bronchiectasis, and paranasal sinus imaging reveals chronic sinusitis. Basic labs, including a complete blood count, are within normal limits. A sweat chloride test is normal. Which of the following additional tests is most likely needed to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: High-resolution computed tomography (CT) of the chest

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old boy presents with a chronic wet cough, recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis, which are characteristic of either cystic fibrosis or primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). However, a negative newborn screen and normal sweat chloride test make cystic fibrosis unlikely, pointing instead toward PCD as the most probable diagnosis. The best next step to evaluate for PCD is nasal nitric oxide (nNO) measurement, as nNO levels are typically markedly reduced due to impaired ciliary function. If levels are low, confirmatory testing includes genetic analysis for PCD-associated mutations and electron microscopy to assess ciliary ultrastructure.       

When evaluating a pediatric patient with a cough, it is important to consider the duration, onset, and associated symptoms to differentiate between upper and lower airway causes. An acute cough lasting less than two weeks with sudden onset may indicate foreign body aspiration, while gradual onset is more typical of upper or lower respiratory tract infections or croup. Chronic cough, defined as persisting for more than four weeks, requires a comprehensive evaluation. Structural airway anomalies typically present in infancy and can be assessed with bronchoscopy. In older children, a cough that is influenced by body position may suggest airway compression from a mediastinal mass, which can be identified through imaging such as chest X-ray, CT, or MRI. A wet, productive cough accompanied by poor weight gain and frequent respiratory infections may indicate cystic fibrosis or primary ciliary dyskinesia. These conditions are evaluated using sweat chloride testing, genetic analysis, and nasal nitric oxide measurement.   

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage:
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy may be helpful in evaluating airway anatomy or identifying infection but does not assess ciliary structure or function. Therefore, it is not diagnostic for primary ciliary dyskinesia, this patient’s most likely diagnosis.
✅ Nasal nitric oxide measurement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ High-resolution computed tomography (CT) of the chest:
Incorrect: High-resolution CT may reveal bronchiectasis, which is further suggestive of primary ciliary dyskinesia, but it would not confirm this patient's underlying defect in ciliary function. 
❌ Nasopharyngeal PCR:
Incorrect: While infections are common in primary ciliary dyskinesia (this patient’s likely diagnosis), chronic symptoms are due to impaired ciliary function rather than persistent infection, making this test unnecessary for diagnosis. 
❌ Immunoglobulin level panel:
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin testing may help identify primary immunodeficiencies. However, the absence of severe or opportunistic infections, along with a normal CBC and newborn screen, makes this diagnosis less likely. This patient’s chronic wet cough, digital clubbing, sinusitis, and bronchiectasis are more consistent with impaired mucociliary clearance.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by EMS after his parent called them because the patient appeared to be struggling to breathe with very noisy breathing. His parent reports that over the past 24 hours, the patient rapidly developed a high fever and a “raspy” voice. He has not been coughing. The patient was born full-term and does not have a significant past medical history; however, his vaccines are not up-to-date. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 144/min, blood pressure is 91/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 45/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The boy appears anxious with difficulty breathing. He is hunched forward on the gurney with his neck extended with audible stridor and drooling. Examination of the throat reveals erythema of the posterior pharynx and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This unvaccinated 7-year-old boy presenting with acute onset of high fevers, difficulty breathing, raspy voice, and tripod positioning likely has epiglottitis. He is currently maintaining his airway, but he is anxious with difficulty breathing and a respiratory rate of 45, indicating impending respiratory failure from upper airway obstruction. Early and definitive airway management is critical. This patient can be transferred to the operating room with the appropriate specialists present in a controlled setting where they can perform rigid bronchoscopy or surgical airway if fiberoptic intubation is unsuccessful.

Acute upper airway obstruction in children can be caused by croup and epiglottitis. Croup, also known as laryngotracheitis, is a common viral infection, caused by the parainfluenza virus or other respiratory viruses, that results in subglottic inflammation and narrowing. Epiglottitis is typically a bacterial infection, most often caused by Haemophilus influenzae, in patients unvaccinated or under-immunized against Haemophilus influenzae, type b (Hib), or Streptococcus pneumoniae. It can lead to rapid and life-threatening swelling of the epiglottis and supraglottic structures.

Acute management of epiglottitis in patients like this one who are maintaining their airway (oxygen saturation of 93% on room air in this patient) but in impending respiratory distress, includes urgent airway management with intubation in a controlled setting. This patient should also be treated with empiric broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (eg, third-generation cephalosporin and coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), IV fluids, secretion management, and supplemental oxygen as needed. Cultures from blood and sputum can be used to tailor antibiotics.

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation in the operating room:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neck X-rays:
Incorrect: Neck X-rays may be ordered in patients with suspected epiglottitis who have a stable airway and are not in impending respiratory distress. A “thumb sign” and swelling of the aryepiglottic folds are pathognomonic for epiglottitis. However, this patient does not have a stable airway and will likely tire, and therefore, needs urgent airway management via fiberoptic intubation in the operating room.
❌ Surgical cricothyrotomy:
Incorrect: Surgical cricothyrotomy is inappropriate given this patient’s age. Also, this patient is in impending respiratory distress and there is no indication of an emergent surgical airway. He should be managed with urgent airway management via fiberoptic intubation in the operating room.
❌ Nebulized racemic epinephrine:
Incorrect: Racemic epinephrine is indicated for patients with moderate to severe croup. This patient’s clinical presentation is indicative of epiglottitis with impending respiratory failure, and he should be managed with fiberoptic intubation in the operating room.
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: Dexamethasone can be used to treat patients with croup. This patient’s clinical presentation is indicative of epiglottitis with impending respiratory failure, and he should be managed with fiberoptic intubation in the operating room.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the primary care office by his parents to be evaluated for coughing and “heavy” breathing. The patient had a fever of 101.4°F three days ago, followed by clear rhinorrhea and cough, but today his breathing seems faster to his parents. He has been nursing normally and has at least 6 wet diapers per day. His 4-year-old sister has had a cold since last week. The patient was born at 41 weeks gestation, weighing 8 pounds, 2 ounces, and has no chronic medical conditions. He has never had wheezing before. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 84/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Weight is in the 75<sup>th</sup> percentile, height is in the 70<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 80<sup>th</sup> percentile. On physical examination, the infant is awake and alert with good tone and movement in all extremities. Mild subcostal retractions are noted. Scattered faint wheezes are noted bilaterally without focal lung findings. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Refer to the emergency department for monitoring

questions.solution:
This child who was born full-term, at an average birth weight, and without a significant past medical history, presents with classic signs of mild bronchiolitis(e.g., alert, mild retractions, a respiratory rate within age-appropriate limits, no apnea, oxygen saturation ≥92%) and can be safely managed with supportive care in the outpatient setting, without additional workup. The provided history of household exposure to someone with an upper respiratory infection makes it very likely the patient acquired a virus such as respiratory syncytial virus from his older sibling.

The diagnostic workup for a child presenting with bronchiolitis varies depending on the age of the patient and severity of the condition. Infants over 28 days old presenting with characteristic features of mild or moderate bronchiolitis can typically be diagnosed clinically, without additional testing or workup, and managed with supportive care. When the diagnosis of bronchiolitis is not straightforward, radiographs and viral testing can be helpful to identify the causative agent and rule out other conditions. Situations where this may be applicable include when a different or secondary condition such as pneumonia is suspected, or when features of severe disease are present.

When indicated, a chest radiograph can be obtained and will typically show hyperinflation and peribronchial thickening, also known as “peribronchial cuffing” (see image below). Neonates with bronchiolitis need special consideration due to the increased likelihood of apneic episodes, as well as consideration of meningitis. Therefore, the workup is more complex in neonates than in older infants and children and may include imaging, blood work, more extensive laboratory testing, and a much lower threshold for hospitalization.
   

Chest radiograph showing peribronchial cuffing by C Michael Gibson is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiMedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Outpatient supportive care:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: This child presents with signs of mild bronchiolitis; a chest X-ray is not routinely indicated when classic characteristics of bronchiolitis are present and the child’s condition is not severe. 
❌ Assess white blood cell count:
Incorrect: Laboratory examination may be indicated in an infant presenting with signs of bronchiolitis depending on age and fever status; febrile neonates need a full workup as well as infants with evidence of concurrent bacterial infection. This child’s age and classic symptoms of mild bronchiolitis do not require further workup at this time.  
❌ Arterial blood gas:
Incorrect: An arterial blood gas is indicated in children with bronchiolitis to assess for respiratory acidosis when severe distress is present or if the child appears to be tired. This child has mild symptoms, is feeding well, and appears stable on examination; therefore, this test is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Refer to the emergency department for monitoring:
Incorrect: This infant has classic signs of mild bronchiolitis, is feeding well, does not require oxygen therapy, and is not lethargic. Outpatient management is reasonable with careful counseling to the parents that the condition may worsen and that they should seek additional care right away for any new or progressive symptoms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parent for evaluation of persistent coughing. The parent states that she has had a dry, non-productive cough for three days. She has not had a runny nose, sore throat, fever, or chills. She has had no sick contacts. The patient loves peanuts and went to the fair four days ago where she had peanuts and popcorn. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate of 90, blood pressure of 96/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 with SpO<sub>2</sub> of 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a well-appearing child with decreased right-sided breath sounds and wheezing anteriorly. Which of the following historical factors, if present, would pose an increased risk for this patient developing a cough?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with three days of persistent coughing in the setting of recent peanut ingestion. Lung exam is notable for decreased breath sounds and wheezing heard over the right anterior lung field. These findings are suggestive of a foreign body aspiration (FBA). Developmental delay in young children can lead to an increased risk of foreign body aspiration and ingestion.

Approximately 80 percent of pediatric FBA episodes occur in children younger than three years of age, with a peak incidence between one and two years of age. At this age, most children can stand, are independently mobile, and have the fine motor skills to put small objects into their mouths. However, they do not have molars or premolars to chew food adequately and may have uncoordinated or immature swallowing mechanisms and a narrow pharynx. Additional predisposing factors to FBA in this age group include access to improper foods or small objects, being active while eating, and older siblings (who may place food or objects into the mouths of infants or toddlers). 

The most common symptom of FBA is a cough, followed by tachypnea and stridor--often with localized wheezing and decreased air entry on physical exam. Regional variation in aeration is an important clue to the diagnosis and is often detected only when the clinician completes a thorough examination while the child is quiet. Nonspecific findings of cough and generalized wheezing are often present.    

Option Analysis

❌ Recent upper respiratory infection:
Incorrect: This patient presents with an acute cough in the setting of recent peanut ingestion. Given her lack of systemic symptoms and sick contacts, her cough is likely from an aspirated foreign body for which developmental delay would be a risk factor. 
❌ Non-peanut nut allergy:
Incorrect: Patients with a non-peanut nut allergy may develop an allergy to peanuts over time. Patients with food allergies present with signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis, including hives and coughing from laryngeal edema. However, this patient’s cough likely developed secondary to a foreign body aspiration for which developmental delay can pose an increased risk. 
✅ Developmental delay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Daycare attendance:
Incorrect: Attending daycare can increase the risk of infection but would not increase the risk of a foreign body aspiration or ingestion. 
❌ Unvaccinated status :
Incorrect: Lack of vaccination does predispose children to a higher risk of infections, such as rotavirus and epiglottitis. This patient does not have systemic symptoms suggestive of infection. Instead, she has isolated coughing in the setting of a likely aspirated peanut. For which developmental delay poses an increased risk.

questions.text: A newborn boy is evaluated after being delivered by c-section at 31 weeks 5 days gestation due to maternal pre-eclampsia. The pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated and there was appropriate prenatal care. Two doses of betamethasone were administered to the mother in the week before delivery. Maternal prenatal labs were negative. The infant is brought to the warmer immediately after delivery. He appears dusky and has a weak cry. Resuscitation is initiated by drying, stimulating, and warming the infant. Bulb suction is used to clear oral and nasal passages. After one minute, the heart rate is 76 bpm. On examination, there is expiratory grunting, diminished breath sounds, and bradycardia. Peripheral pulses are diminished. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is born prematurely at 31 weeks 5 days gestation due to preeclampsia. Neonatal resuscitation protocol should begin in the delivery room with drying, stimulating, warming, and bulb suctioning. This infant continues to be bradycardic and with signs of respiratory distress including grunting and diminished breath sounds. This patient’s respiratory distress is likely secondary to neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is a complication of prematurity. The best next step in the acute management of this patient is to initiate positive pressure ventilation. 

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants, especially for infants born before 32 weeks' gestation. It is secondary to surfactant deficiency, which is produced by alveolar cells starting at 24-26 weeks' gestation and reaching mature levels at 34-36 weeks' gestation. Newborn patients with respiratory distress syndrome present with progressive respiratory insufficiency shortly after birth.

The initial step in the management of RDS is Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) assessment to ensure patient stability. If the patient has any form of respiratory drive, noninvasive positive pressure ventilation is recommended first. If the patient is apneic or has poor respiratory effort, then endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation is indicated. The goal oxygen saturations for patients with RDS is 90-95%. Following airway stabilization, access should be obtained, usually via an umbilical venous catheter and surfactant should be given.   

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate positive pressure ventilation (PPV) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Place an umbilical vein catheter (UVC) :
Incorrect: Although this patient requires access, he is in respiratory distress and the first step in management is to initiate positive pressure ventilation.  
❌ Intubate:
Incorrect: As per neonatal resuscitation guidelines, the first step in managing a newborn in respiratory distress is to dry and stimulate them and clear secretions. If the infant continues to have respiratory distress or bradycardia, positive pressure ventilation with a mask should be provided. If positive pressure ventilation is unsuccessful, then the patient should be intubated. 
❌ Administer surfactant:
Incorrect: Surfactant is administered to preterm newborns with respiratory distress syndrome once they are stabilized. It is usually administered after intubation should this procedure be necessary. The best next step for this patient is to initiate positive pressure ventilation. 
❌ Perform deep suctioning:
Incorrect: Bulb suctioning is often used to clear oral and nasal passages; however, deep suctioning is not indicated during initial resuscitative measures. The best next step is to initiate positive pressure ventilation.

questions.text:
A 1300-gram newborn male is delivered at 28 weeks’ gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgars are four and seven at one and five minutes, respectively. Immediately after delivery, the newborn requires resuscitation and is placed on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and then admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). Before delivery, the pregnancy was uneventful with normal maternal labs. Rupture of the membranes was eight hours before delivery. The mother did not receive betamethasone before delivery. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F) and stable, pulse is 168/min, respirations are 64/min, blood pressure is 48/25 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on nasal CPAP with 0.4 FiO2. On examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and flat. The infant is tachypneic with subcostal retractions, grunting, and nasal flaring. Auscultation reveals decreased air entry throughout the lung fields bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal, and no murmurs are heard. The abdominal exam is unremarkable. Umbilical lines are in place. The chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Häggström et al. Reproduced from Wikipedia.  Licensed under CC0.
questions.solution:
This premature infant requiring resuscitation was born at 28 weeks’ gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who did not receive antenatal betamethasone. The infant continues to have tachypnea, nasal flaring, retractions, and grunting despite continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). The chest radiograph shows ground glass opacities and air bronchograms consistent with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). This infant requires immediate stabilization with intubation and surfactant administration.

Neonatal RDS is caused by surfactant deficiency which results in progressive atelectasis with inability to inflate the lungs. In addition to prematurity, risk factors for RDS include male sex, white race, absence of labor, maternal history of diabetes, and lack of maternal antenatal corticosteroid administration. Premature newborns with respiratory distress syndrome may present with nasal flaring, grunting, and chest wall retractions indicating respiratory distress. Respiratory distress in newborns can be related to an underlying cardiovascular or pulmonary pathology. If there is no murmur, and lung auscultation reveals poor air entry throughout both lung fields, neonatal RDS is the likely diagnosis, and a chest radiograph should be ordered. A chest x-ray revealing ground glass opacities with air bronchograms and low lung volumes can confirm the diagnosis.

Premature newborns who develop respiratory distress should have an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment. In patients with RDS and signs of respiratory distress despite noninvasive respiratory support, as seen in this patient, intubation and surfactant administration (depending on the degree of prematurity and chest radiograph findings) is indicated to stabilize the airway and breathing.

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous ampicillin and ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Newborns delivered prematurely are often started on empiric antibiotics while awaiting lab results; however, ampicillin and ceftriaxone are not the appropriate antibiotics. This patient has findings consistent with respiratory distress syndrome and requires emergent intubation and surfactant administration first.
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: While congenital heart defects and other cardiac conditions such as persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) can lead to respiratory distress, this newborn has respiratory distress syndrome and requires immediate intubation and surfactant administration for stabilization.
✅ Intubation and administration of surfactant  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous prostaglandins:
Incorrect: Intravenous prostaglandins are used in patients with ductal-dependent cyanotic congenital heart disease to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus and systemic circulation. This newborn has respiratory distress syndrome and requires immediate intubation and surfactant administration for stabilization.
❌ Cranial ultrasound:
Incorrect: Cranial ultrasound is performed in premature infants to diagnose intraventricular hemorrhage. This newborn has respiratory distress syndrome and requires emergent intubation and surfactant administration for stabilization first.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old newborn female delivered at 32 weeks’ gestation is in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) and being evaluated for multiple episodes of witnessed apnea lasting 20 to 30 seconds each. Parents are consanguineous (distant cousins), and pregnancy was complicated by maternal gestational diabetes. The infant was delivered via C-section for non-reassuring fetal heart rate, and delivery was uneventful. Due to prematurity, the infant is currently receiving intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin while awaiting blood culture results. The patient is also receiving nutrition through a nasogastric tube. There are no fevers, seizures, gastric residuals, or abnormal stools. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and stable, pulse is 168/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 55/28 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on two liters nasal cannula with 28% FiO2. On examination, no dysmorphic features are noted. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Nasogastric tube and umbilical lines are in place. Auscultation of the lungs reveals good air entry bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal with no murmur or cyanosis. The abdominal exam is unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Abdominal and chest X-rays are normal. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for apnea in this patient?  
 
 Laboratory value     Results    
 Hemoglobin      15 g/dL    
 Hematocrit      45%    
 White blood cells     8,000/mm3    
 Platelets      290,000/mm3    
 Sodium      137 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4 mEq/L    
 Blood glucose      55 mg/dL    
 PH     7.39    
 PCO2     40 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate (HCO3)     22 mEq/L    
 Blood culture     No growth to date
questions.solution:
This premature newborn has had multiple episodes of cessation of breathing for more than 20 seconds. In the absence of an underlying pathology, this patient can be diagnosed with apnea of prematurity. Premature infants, especially those under 37 weeks' gestation, can have apnea due to poor development of the mechanisms of respiratory control.

Apnea of prematurity occurs in infants younger than 37 weeks' gestation and is defined as cessation of breathing for over 20 seconds (or a shorter respiratory pause associated with desaturations or bradycardias). While immature respiratory control is the primary cause of apnea in premature infants, other factors can potentiate or worsen apnea; these other causes should be ruled out, including infections, feeding difficulties, necrotizing enterocolitis, central nervous system pathology (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, seizures), hypoglycemia, electrolyte imbalances, and anemia. Premature infants experiencing apnea require a comprehensive evaluation to identify the underlying cause. Apnea of prematurity is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Option Analysis

❌ Consanguinity :
Incorrect: Consanguinity increases the risk of autosomal recessive genetic disorders, which can lead to congenital anomalies. It is not a risk factor for apnea in and of itself. This infant is more likely to have apnea due to prematurity.
❌ Formula feeding :
Incorrect: Formula feeding increases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in premature infants. Patients with NEC present with abdominal distention, feeding intolerance, and occasionally apnea. This patient has no gastrointestinal issues and a normal abdominal examination, making apnea due to prematurity more likely.
❌ Maternal gestational diabetes :
Incorrect: Maternal gestational diabetes is a known risk factor for neonatal hypoglycemia, which can manifest as jitteriness, irritability, apnea, or seizures. However, this infant’s normal glucose levels make hypoglycemia an unlikely cause of the apnea, which is more likely due to prematurity.
❌ Intravenous gentamicin administration :
Incorrect: Intravenous aminoglycosides increase the risk of nephrotoxicity and hearing loss but do not increase the risk of apnea.
✅ Prematurity :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A newborn boy born at 39 weeks gestation who is 7 hours old is in the neonatal intensive care unit with persistent respiratory distress that started 1 hour after delivery. He was delivered by cesarean delivery for fetal macrosomia. Maternal history is positive for gestational diabetes with normal prenatal ultrasound. There was no history of maternal fever and GBS was negative. Amniotic fluid was clear and there were no complications at delivery. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 165 beats/minute, respiratory rate is 84/minute, and Oxygen saturation is 91% on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with 50% FiO2. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, subcostal retractions with nasal flaring, and diffuse crackles in both lung fields. No heart murmur is heard. The patient has normal pulses bilaterally. Abdominal exam is normal. Initial lab results are shown below. Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Hemoglobin
18 g/dL  
Hematocrit
48 %  
Leukocyte count  
9,800/mm3   
Platelet count  
280,000/mm3   
PH
7.30  
PCO2
52 mmHg  
PO2
80 mmHg  
Bicarbonate (HCO3)  
21 mEq/L  
Base deficit  
-3

choices.text: Bowel loops in left hemithorax on chest x-ray
Fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs on chest x-ray
Left to right shunt on echocardiogram

questions.solution:
This newborn with a maternal history of gestational diabetes who was delivered by cesarean section presents with respiratory distress beyond 6 hours of life. This is consistent with transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN), which can be confirmed by obtaining a chest x-ray that shows fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs.

TTN is caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid after birth, which leads to ineffective gas exchange and respiratory distress. Risk factors for TTN include cesarean delivery, precipitous delivery, and maternal diabetes. TTN typically presents shortly after birth with respiratory distress and persists beyond 6 hours of life. If symptoms resolve within the first 6 hours of life, then it is classified as delayed transition of the newborn. Typical physical exam findings include tachypnea, grunting, retractions, hypoxia requiring oxygen supplementation, and diffuse crackles in bilateral lung fields.

The diagnostic workup for an infant with respiratory distress should include obtaining labs such as a complete blood count (CBC) and blood gas. A CBC may help rule out anemia and infections such as neonatal sepsis and neonatal pneumonia. In this newborn, the CBC shows no evidence of anemia or leukocytosis. Blood gas is obtained to evaluate gas exchange and acid-base balance. The blood gas in this patient shows mild respiratory acidosis which is expected with transient tachypnea of the newborn.

Chest x-ray is essential to exclude other causes of respiratory distress in the newborn such as respiratory distress syndrome, meconium aspiration syndrome, and pneumothorax. Typical chest x-ray findings of TTN include the presence of pulmonary edema, with diffuse increased interstitial lung markings, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs. A lung ultrasound will demonstrate double lung points. An echocardiogram should be obtained if the newborn experiences persistent respiratory distress despite adequate treatment to rule out persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).
 
Image Courtesy of STATdx

Option Analysis

❌ Bowel loops in left hemithorax on chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Bowel loops in the left hemithorax on chest x-ray are seen in patients with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) which is commonly diagnosed on prenatal ultrasound and presents with scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds heard on chest exam. The newborn in this case had a normal prenatal ultrasound and physical exam findings are not consistent with CDH.  
❌ Compact B-lines on lung ultrasound:
Incorrect: Compact B-lines on lung ultrasound are seen with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) and preterm newborns with RDS typically present with tachypnea, grunting, retractions, and nasal flaring immediately after birth. This full-term newborn with precipitous cesarean delivery is unlikely to have respiratory distress syndrome.  
✅ Fluid in the horizontal fissures of the lungs on chest x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left to right shunt on echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Left to right shunt on echocardiogram is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) which is seen more commonly in premature infants and presents with a continuous machinery-like murmur and bounding peripheral pulses. This newborn does not have a heart murmur and has normal pulses which makes PDA a less likely cause of his symptoms.  
❌ Positive blood cultures:
Incorrect: Positive blood cultures are seen in infectious causes of respiratory distress such as neonatal sepsis or neonatal pneumonia. This newborn doesn't have temperature instability, no focal lung findings, and no risk factors for infections (maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, positive GBS, prolonged membrane rupture).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent for a “barking” cough and nasal congestion for the past 3 days. Today her parent noticed she was having difficulty breathing. She was diagnosed with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), 3 days ago by her pediatrician when her symptoms started. She was born at 33 weeks gestation and was briefly hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), but otherwise has no significant past medical history. Vaccines are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 107/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air with good air entry. The patient is awake and alert and has stridor at rest with moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions. Oral examination reveals erythematous changes of the posterior pharynx with moist mucous membranes. Based on these findings, the patient is given intramuscular dexamethasone. Which of the following clinical features is an indication for treatment with nebulized racemic epinephrine?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic clinical features of moderate croup including stridor at rest and moderate retractions. All patients with croup can be treated with dexamethasone; however, not all patients require treatment with nebulized racemic epinephrine. Patients like this one with moderate symptoms should be treated with nebulized racemic epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.

Patients with croup are typically between 6 months and 3 years old, and present with a low-grade fever and signs and symptoms of upper respiratory infection that can progress to a barking or seal-like cough, hoarseness, and stridor. The cough may worsen at night. Physical examination should assess for the presence of stridor (and whether it is present at rest), and the presence and severity of retractions, along with signs of respiratory distress. These features can be used to determine the severity of illness, which will then guide management.

Nebulized racemic epinephrine works by reducing airway edema and thus reducing stridor and work of breathing. Patients who receive a single dose of epinephrine should be monitored for 2-3 hours after administration to ensure that rebound edema and rebound symptoms do not occur. If rebound symptoms occur, patients should be hospitalized and given humidified oxygen along with symptomatic care (e.g. cool mist treatments) and repeat racemic epinephrine doses.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Stridor at rest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Age is not a determining factor for the administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest, and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ History of prematurity:
Incorrect: History of prematurity is not a determining factor for the administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ Preceding viral illness:
Incorrect: Preceding illness is not a determining factor for administration of racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest, and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.
❌ Oxygen saturation:
Incorrect: Oxygen saturation is not a determining factor for administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine in patients with croup. Stridor at rest and moderate retractions are indications for the administration of racemic epinephrine.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by her parents for difficulty breathing and poor feeding. She has had rhinorrhea and a cough for three days with a maximum temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F) at home. Starting this morning, she has been refusing to nurse for more than a few seconds at a time and has only had two wet diapers. That evening, at bedtime, her breathing became faster, and her abdomen appeared to be moving significantly when she was breathing. She was born at 35 weeks gestation and has no chronic medical conditions or prior wheezing episodes. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 162/min, respiratory rate is 62/min, blood pressure is 84/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Weight is in the 62<sup>nd</sup> percentile, height is in the 55<sup>th</sup> percentile and head circumference is in the 61<sup>st</sup> percentile. On physical examination, the child appears awake and alert with active movement of all extremities. The anterior fontanelle is sunken and there is poor skin turgor. Moderate intercostal retractions and abdominal breathing are noted. Lung examination reveals diffuse bilateral crackles with faint expiratory wheezes. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with classic features of bronchiolitis and has evidence of dehydration likely due to poor oral intake. The reduced number of wet diapers, sunken anterior fontanelle (see image below), and poor skin turgor indicate the child’s volume needs are not being met orally, and she should therefore be hospitalized and started on intravenous fluids.

The mainstay of treatment for children with bronchiolitis is supportive care. This may range from outpatient monitoring of the child’s condition and encouragement of oral fluid intake to more invasive modalities such as nasal suctioning, intravenous hydration, and supplemental oxygen with hospital admission.

Children with bronchiolitis can have difficulty with oral intake due to nasal congestion as well as increased breathing. Gentle nasal suctioning of the anterior nasal passages can help clear mucus and make it easier to breathe, but deep suctioning should be avoided as it can worsen the child’s condition. Supplemental oxygen is usually started when oxygen saturation falls below 90%, and patients may require endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation in severe cases. A trial of nebulized hypertonic saline can be considered, but there is variation in practice with this approach.

Treatment can be provided in either the inpatient or outpatient setting, depending on factors such as the age of the child, risk factors for severe disease, and severity of disease at presentation. Another important factor to consider when making a treatment plan is the caregiver’s ability to provide adequate monitoring and supportive care to the child at home, as well as their ability to access additional healthcare services if needed.
     

Sunken anterior fontanelle of a 1 month old newborn by Johann Dréo is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiMedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Routine use of systemic corticosteroids is not indicated in bronchiolitis, especially without a reported history of recurrent wheezing episodes. 
❌ Palivizumab:
Incorrect: Palivizumab is used for prophylaxis against respiratory syncytial virus in high-risk infants. It is not helpful after infection with the virus, and therefore is not recommended as a treatment for bronchiolitis. 
❌ Ampicillin :
Incorrect: Empiric coverage with antibiotics may be indicated when the diagnosis of bronchiolitis is uncertain and signs of bacterial infection are present, or in febrile neonates less than 28 days old. Bronchiolitis is caused by viruses, and therefore routine use of antibiotics is not indicated.  
❌ Deep suctioning:
Incorrect: Nasal suctioning can be helpful in the management of bronchiolitis; however, deep suctioning should be avoided as it can worsen the child’s condition and lengthen the hospital stay. This is likely due to local trauma caused by the catheter tip leading to edema and irritation of the upper airway.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a high fever of 102°F (38.9°C) yesterday. Shortly after the fever started, the patient began drooling and he had decreased oral intake at dinner. The patient was given acetaminophen, which helped lower the fever, but this morning he woke up with a fever, painful swallowing, and neck stiffness. He has no cough or wheezing. The patient is otherwise healthy, fully vaccinated, and meeting developmental milestones. Temperature is 101.5 °F (38.6 °C), heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 100/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 42, and SpO2 of 92% on room air. The patient is drooling, and his neck is in hyperextension. There is no evidence of nasal rhinorrhea or congestion. Physical examination is notable for right-sided swelling of the posterior pharynx with associated erythema and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient refuses to move the neck, and there is a limited passive range of motion of the neck due to pain. Labs are notable for leukocytosis to 18.6 x 109/L. Lateral neck x-ray demonstrates widening of the retropharyngeal space. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with drooling, dysphagia, neck hyperextension, and stiffness (torticollis) and is found to have a fever, increased respiratory rate, decreased oxygen saturation, and leukocytosis. Physical exam is notable for unilateral swelling of the posterior pharynx and limited range of motion of the neck secondary to pain, Lateral neck x-ray shows widening of the retropharyngeal space. These findings are consistent with a retropharyngeal abscess, and a dedicated CT with IV contrast should be ordered next.        

Signs and symptoms of nasopharyngeal obstruction include audible stertor or stridor as the disease progresses and visible tonsillar or pharyngeal swelling along with respiratory distress. Causes of nasopharyngeal upper airway obstruction include retropharyngeal abscess, peritonsillar abscess, tonsillitis, and adenotonsillar hypertrophy.        

Retropharyngeal abscess is typically due to polymicrobial bacterial infection and can progress and lead to respiratory distress. Rapid assessment of the degree of upper airway obstruction is the first step in the evaluation, and intubation with the aid of an anesthesiologist or intensivist and an otolaryngologist may be necessarily followed by surgical drainage.   

Option Analysis

❌ Croup :
Incorrect: Patients with croup typically present with symptoms of upper respiratory infection and rapid onset of barking or a seal-like cough that worsens at night, inspiratory stridor, and have normal oxygenation. This patient is not coughing and has decreased oxygenation.  
❌ Epiglottitis  :
Incorrect: A similar presentation can be seen in epiglottis but typically patients with epiglottitis drool and lean forward (tripod position) instead of hyper-extending the neck, and, on exam, patients with epiglottitis typically have a cherry-red epiglottis. Lateral x-ray would show a “thumb” sign and swelling of the aryepiglottic folds, not widening of the retropharyngeal space as seen in this patient with retropharyngeal abscess. 
✅ Retropharyngeal abscess :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peritonsillar abscess :
Incorrect: A similar presentation can be seen in patients with peritonsillar abscess; however, a “hot potato” voice would be expected. On exam, unilateral tonsillar bulging with or without uvular deviation would be seen. 
❌ Streptococcal pharyngitis/tonsillitis  :
Incorrect: Patients with this condition typically present with fever, sore throat, constitutional symptoms, and lymphadenopathy. On examination, the tonsils would appear enlarged with associated exudates.

questions.text: A 2.5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of limpness and cyanosis. The father states that the patient was sitting in his arms when he suddenly lost muscle tone and became blue. He states the episode lasted about 30 seconds and the patient immediately returned to his baseline. The patient was born at 30 weeks' gestation. The patient’s parent has a history of a congenital heart defect, and the father has a seizure disorder. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 94/55mmHg, pulse is 138/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat, mucus membranes are moist, cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and no rashes or ecchymosis are noted. Which of the following historical features indicates the need for further workups?

choices.text: Maternal history of congenital heart disease

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) including cyanosis and decreased muscle tone lasting less than one minute with return to baseline after the event. Patients with high-risk features should have close monitoring and further inpatient evaluation. In the setting of a BRUE, prematurity is a high-risk factor that warrants further evaluation. Therefore, this patient who was born at 30 weeks of gestation needs inpatient observation and further evaluation.

Based on historical features and exam findings, infants who meet the criteria for BRUE are classified into high and low-risk categories. Patients considered high-risk should be admitted for observation, supportive care, and further evaluation. Potential underlying causes of a BRUE-like event include infectious processes, inborn errors of metabolism, cardiovascular anomalies, gastroesophageal reflux/laryngospasm, epilepsy, and child abuse. When a clear precipitating event is not apparent on history or physical examination, a work-up should include pulse oximetry monitoring, electrocardiogram, hematocrit, blood glucose, bicarbonate or venous blood gas, lactic acid, respiratory virus testing panel, and testing for pertussis. It is also important to review newborn screening test results.

In contrast, patients with low-risk features are typically discharged without observation or further evaluation. A brief in-hospital observation, electrocardiogram, and testing for pertussis or other respiratory viruses can be considered but are not required. These patients can be safely discharged following parental education and ensuring close follow-up.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Birth at 30 weeks of gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal history of congenital heart disease:
Incorrect: A maternal history of a congenital heart defect does not classify a patient who has experienced a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) as high-risk and requiring further workup. 
❌ Paternal history of seizure disorder :
Incorrect: A paternal history of seizure disorder does not classify a patient who has experienced a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) as high-risk and requiring further workup. 
❌ Age of 2.5 months:
Incorrect: Infants greater than 2 months old at the time of a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) are considered low-risk and do not warrant further evaluation if no other high-risk features are present. 
❌ Episode lasting 30 seconds :
Incorrect: Episodes that last less than one minute are considered low-risk and do not indicate the need for further workup to evaluate for an underlying etiology.

questions.text: A newborn girl is born prematurely via spontaneous vaginal delivery. There was appropriate prenatal care. Maternal prenatal labs were negative. The infant develops respiratory distress within 10 minutes after delivery. After failing to respond to positive pressure ventilation in the delivery room, the infant is intubated. The neonatologist informs the parents that the patient would benefit from administration of surfactant. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 35/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on mechanical ventilation. On physical examination, the infant is intubated with noted improvement in respiration. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Heart rate is normal, and no murmur is appreciated. In addition to prematurity, which of the following would be considered a risk factor for this patient’s likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Administration of steroids to the mother prior to delivery
Prenatal ultrasound showing gallbladder above the diaphragm

questions.solution:
This patient born prematurely has evidence of respiratory distress shortly after delivery and is subsequently intubated. The provider recommends treatment with surfactant. Exogenous surfactant is used to treat respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), associated with exceptionally low birth weight in infants.

Respiratory distress syndrome is a common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants and commonly occurs secondary to surfactant deficiency. Surfactants are typically produced by alveolar cells between 24-36 weeks' gestation. If preterm labor is suspected, mothers are given intramuscular corticosteroids to stimulate alveolar surfactant production.

Patients with RDS typically present with progressive respiratory insufficiency that starts minutes to hours after delivery. Patients are often tachypneic with a respiratory rate >60 bpm with associated grunting, retractions, and nasal flaring. On auscultation, there will be poor air movement and occasionally crackles. Patients are often hypoxemic with oxygen saturation <90%.

Respiratory distress syndrome is most common in infants born between 23-29 weeks' gestation and is associated with exceptionally low birth weight in infants (defined as infants <1500 grams). Prenatal ultrasounds are typically normal. Other risk factors include multiple gestation pregnancies, male sex, maternal diabetes, fetal distress or asphyxia, c-section delivery without labor, and family history of neonatal RDS.   

Option Analysis

✅ Very low birth weight (VLBW) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gestational age of 37 weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) which is associated with prematurity (especially infants born < 32 weeks' gestation). Thirty-seven weeks is considered full-term and would not be a risk factor.  
❌ Polyhydramnios:
Incorrect: This patient has respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is not associated with polyhydramnios. Respiratory distress syndrome is seen in infants with exceptionally low birth weight (VLBW). 
❌ Administration of steroids to the mother prior to delivery:
Incorrect: antenatal corticosteroids are often administered to mothers at risk for preterm labor to stimulate surfactant production to prevent respiratory distress syndrome. Administration decreases the risk of respiratory distress syndrome.  
❌ Prenatal ultrasound showing gallbladder above the diaphragm:
Incorrect: Prenatal ultrasound showing the gallbladder above the diaphragm is consistent with a diaphragmatic hernia. While this can cause respiratory distress, it would not respond to surfactant administration and surfactant would not be recommended by the provider. This patient’s likely diagnosis is respiratory distress syndrome which is associated with exceptionally low birth weight (VLBW).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of shortness of breath and chest tightness for the past hour. The patient appears tachypneic but is able to speak in full sentences. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder in the patient’s father. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing bilaterally in all lung fields. After further evaluation, treatment with an inhaled medication is begun. The patient reports improvement in symptoms which was evident by increased flow rate on spirometry. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug used to manage this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-mediated smooth muscle relaxation
Cell membrane stabilization of mast cells
Opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells

questions.solution:
This young patient’s presentation with acute shortness of breath and chest tightness, together with examination findings of diffuse wheezing, is consistent with airway bronchoconstriction, most likely due to an asthma attack. Administration of a bronchodilator, most likely a beta-2 (β2) agonist (e.g. albuterol) improved his symptoms.

Bronchodilation is accomplished by the inhalation of β2 agonists, which bind to the β2 adrenergic receptors on bronchial smooth muscle cells. This activates the enzyme adenylyl cyclase which leads to increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production that ultimately causes relaxation of the smooth muscle by reducing the concentration of intracellular calcium (Ca+2) ions.

It also stimulates the β2 receptors on mast cells and decreases the release of inflammatory mediators (e.g., leukotrienes and prostaglandins). This, in turn, decreases inflammation, swelling, and irritation in the respiratory tract.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-mediated smooth muscle relaxation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cell membrane stabilization of mast cells:
Incorrect: Cromolyn sodium stabilizes the membrane of mast cells and prevents its degranulation (release of histamine and leukotrienes). Although it is one of the treatment options for the management of chronic asthma, it does not resolve acute asthmatic attacks.  
❌ Opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: The opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells by calcium agonists can worsen the condition by inducing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Such drugs are contraindicated in acute asthma attacks.  
❌ Inhibition of eosinophil differentiation:
Incorrect: Anti-IL-5 monoclonal antibody (e.g.-Mepolizumab) therapy prevents eosinophil differentiation, maturation, activation, and survival mediated by IL-5 stimulation. It is only approved for use in patients with severe refractory asthma with serum eosinophil counts >150 cells/mcL.  
❌ Inhibition of eosinophil degranulation:
Incorrect: Corticosteroid administration can inhibit eosinophil degradation and it plays an important role in the management of acute asthma attacks. However, in contrast to beta-agonists, corticosteroids take several hours to days to take effect.

questions.text:
A newborn boy is delivered via vaginal delivery at 28 weeks gestation because of preterm labor. There is no maternal fever and GBS is negative. The newborn weighs 1500-g (3.3 lbs). Apgar scores are 2 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He requires continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) immediately after delivery for respiratory distress. In the NICU, temperature is 36.8°C ( 98.2°F), pulse is 175 beats/min, and respiratory rate is 78/min with SpO2 70% on supplemental oxygen at FiO2 100%. On physical examination, the patient has subcostal retractions, grunting, and nasal flaring. Auscultation reveals decreased air entry in the bilateral lung fields throughout. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This preterm infant presents shortly after birth with tachypnea, increased work of breathing, hypoxia, and a chest x-ray showing ground glass appearance of the lung fields, which is consistent with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). This patient has failed a trial of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and has hypoxia at oxygen supplementation of FiO2 100%, therefore he should be intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.

RDS is the most common cause of respiratory distress in the preterm newborn and incidence peaks at 72-96 hours after birth. Preterm infants are at risk for RDS due to underdeveloped lungs and surfactant deficiency. Term infants born to diabetic mothers are also at risk of RDS due to fetal hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia disrupting surfactant synthesis. Surfactant deficiency leads to alveolar collapse and atelectasis which results in impaired ventilation and gas exchange.

Physical exam of a newborn with RDS can reveal decreased air entry in the lungs, tachypnea (respiratory rate > 60/min), grunting, nasal flaring, subcostal or intercostal retractions, and crackles might be heard upon auscultation. Chest x-ray can show bilateral ground glass appearance with air bronchograms and hypoexpansion. A chest ultrasound will show compact B lines with an echographic white lung appearance.

The first step in the management of a newborn with respiratory distress is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. In this unstable preterm infant in respiratory distress with hypoxia not responding to supplemental oxygen, the best next step is to ensure adequate breathing and oxygenation by intubation and starting mechanical ventilation. Surfactants should also be given in severe cases of respiratory distress syndrome to decrease the risk of pneumothorax and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: Blood cultures should be obtained if neonatal sepsis is suspected. Sepsis is typically associated with maternal fever and chorioamnionitis. This patient has signs of respiratory distress and needs to be stabilized before laboratory testing is obtained.  
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Congenital heart defects or patent ductus arteriosus can lead to respiratory distress in the newborn. After stabilizing this patient in respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure, an echocardiogram can be obtained.  
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous (IV) antibiotics should be started if the etiology suspected is infectious such as pneumonia or neonatal sepsis. For this unstable patient in respiratory distress, intubation with mechanical ventilation is the priority.  
❌ Observe and recheck in 1 hour:
Incorrect: This preterm newborn presents with tachypnea, increased work of breathing, and is not responding to supplemental oxygen and has a chest x-ray consistent with respiratory distress syndrome. Delayed intubation and mechanical ventilation will lead to respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents for trouble breathing. He had mild upper respiratory symptoms starting three days ago with rhinorrhea and cough but developed difficulty breathing around bedtime that evening. He had a temperature of 101.1°F earlier today. His three-year-old brother had a cold last week. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 156/min, respiratory rate is 54/min, blood pressure is 86/42 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Weight is in the 64<sup>th</sup> percentile, height is in the 70<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 66<sup>th</sup> percentile. On physical examination, the infant is calm and alert in his parent’s lap. Increased work of breathing is present with moderate subcostal and suprasternal retractions. Diffuse bilateral expiratory wheezing is noted on lung exam. There is no stridor and no focal lung findings. Which of the following would indicate the need for hospitalization for treatment of the acute condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with classic features of bronchiolitis, a lung infection that can be caused by several different viruses.
