A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea on exertion. She has lost 25 lbs over the past three months and has experienced decreased appetite. The shortness of breath is worse when lying flat. In addition, she has been intermittently coughing up blood-streaked sputum. The patient has not seen a physician in twenty years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for thirty years and drinks one to two beers nightly. She does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a cachectic female with moderately increased work of breathing and dullness to percussion over the right lung base. A chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with increased work of breathing, weight loss, and a large right-sided pleural effusion. In this setting, without signs of hemodynamic instability, the most appropriate management involves thoracentesis, which will provide diagnostic and therapeutic benefits for this patient.  

Thoracentesis is a percutaneous procedure wherein fluid is removed from the pleural space via needle aspiration. When performed correctly, large volumes of fluid can be removed (more than one liter), allowing for lung re-expansion, improved oxygenation, and reduced work of breathing. In addition to therapeutic benefit, aspirated pleural fluid can be analyzed to determine if it is exudative versus transudative and evaluate for the presence of malignant cells.  

The preferred site for thoracentesis is on the affected side of the chest in either the midaxillary line or the posterior midscapular line. Before the procedure, ultrasound guidance should be employed to accurately identify a safe site to insert the needle to avoid abdominal structures (e.g. the liver) and the inferior border of the lung. Once an appropriate site has been identified, the area is sterilized and injected with local analgesia. Next, the thoracentesis needle is advanced over the rib to prevent damage to the intercostal vessels and nerves (which run below each rib). Finally, the catheter is advanced, and fluid is aspirated for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chest tube placement:
Incorrect: Given the concern for a malignant effusion and no evidence of trauma or hemodynamic instability, a chest tube is not immediately indicated in treating this patient’s condition.   
❌ Needle decompression :
Incorrect: This patient lacks signs of tension physiology (e.g., hypotension, mediastinal shift), making needle decompression of little clinical utility. 
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: Diuresis may assist in volume reduction. However, it is not the definitive diagnostic or therapeutic treatment for patients with a large pleural effusion.
❌ Dialysis :
Incorrect: Dialysis may assist in volume reduction. However, dialysis will not provide diagnostic information regarding the underlying etiology of this patient’s condition.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for evaluation of dull chest pain for the past two months. The pain is more profound in the right chest and worsens with physical activity. A chest radiograph is obtained as part of the work-up and shown below. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of this image?  


Image reproduced from SAEM
questions.solution:
A chest x-ray was appropriately obtained in the workup of this patient’s symptoms. The above image demonstrates adequate inspiratory effort, underpenetration, and midline alignment.  

When reviewing a chest x-ray, it is important to assess its quality and technical view, which describes whether an image is taken anterior-posterior (AP) or posterior-anterior (PA). Quality is based on a combination of three metrics:  

The first metric is penetration, which describes the extent to which the x-rays have passed through the patient’s body. If a study is adequately penetrated, then the lower thoracic spine should be visualized through the cardiac shadow. If the lower thoracic spine is not visualized, the study is under-penetrated. In contrast, in an over-penetrated study, too many x-rays pass through low density structures, causing the lung fields to appear black, increasing the risk that pathologic findings are missed.

The second metric is inspiration. In a film with adequate inspiratory effort, 8-10 posterior ribs can be seen above the diaphragm.  

The final metric is rotation, which can be determined by evaluating the relationship between the clavicles and the spine. If the medial ends of the clavicles are equidistant from the thoracic spinous process, then the patient is midline and not rotated.  


Option Analysis

✅  Penetration Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  Adequate  Midline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  inadequate  Midline :
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. The patient demonstrates adequate respiratory effort since the posterior aspects of over eight ribs can be seen.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  Adequate Right anterior oblique:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates under-penetration and adequate inspiratory effort. Moreover, the image is well-aligned since the spinous processes lie approximately half-way between the medial ends of the clavicles, indicating that the patient is midline.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Overrpenetrated  Inadequate  Midline :
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated, not overpenetrated, since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. 
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation Overpenetrated  Adequate  Left anterior oblique:
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated, not overpenetrated, since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. Moreover, there is no evidence of rotation since the spinous processes lie approximately half-way between the medial ends of the clavicles, indicating that the patient is midline.

questions.text:
56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. Over the past week, the patient has been experiencing persistent chest pain, worsening with deep inhalation but not with exertion. The pain is described as “sharp,” and she states that she is also experiencing similar pain in her shoulders. Of note, she is currently receiving treatment for breast cancer. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a thin female with moderate tachypnea. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals hyperdynamic S1 and S2 without gallups, rubs, or murmurs. Musculoskeletal examination of the back and upper extremities is unremarkable. The patient’s initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s pain?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with breast cancer presents with pleuritic chest pain, of which the differential diagnosis is broad. Potential causes include infectious, thrombotic, and inflammatory etiologies. Given this patient’s referred shoulder pain and diminished breath sounds, her presentation is most consistent with pleuritic chest pain secondary to pleural effusions and subsequent diaphragmatic irritation.  

Pleuritic chest pain refers to pain characterized by sudden and intensely sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. Most lung tissue does not contain somatic pain fibers, aside from the parietal pleural and the intercostal nerves that line the inner chest wall. Disease processes that irritate these nerve endings manifest with pleuritic pain. The list of potential causes for pleuritic chest pain is broad and includes pneumothorax, rheumatologic diseases, pneumonia, empyema, pulmonary embolism, pericarditis, and pleural effusions.   

Of note, pleural effusions and hemothoraces layer on the diaphragm, irritating it and resulting in referred pain to the shoulder. This phenomenon exists because the central diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve, supplied by spinal levels C3, C4, and C5. These spinal levels also provide innervation to the root of the neck and shoulder.   

Option Analysis

✅ Central diaphragm :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericarditis is another common etiology of pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s electrocardiogram is without evidence of repolarization abnormalities or diffuse ST elevations and only demonstrates sinus tachycardia. As a result, the diagnosis of underlying pericarditis is unlikely in this patient.
❌ Superior aspect of the pleura :
Incorrect: Infection, malignancy, or thrombosis at the superior aspect of the pleura may result in pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and physical exam are more consistent with bilateral pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation. 
❌ Left anterior descending artery :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) manifests with cardiac chest pain, often described as pressure or “an elephant sitting on my chest.” It is less commonly associated with pleuritic chest pain. Most importantly, this patient's electrocardiogram does not show any anterior ST-segment changes.
❌ Pulmonary artery :
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism is an essential diagnostic consideration in evaluating pleuritic chest pain. However, given this patient has diminished breath sounds bilaterally, her clinical presentation is more consistent with pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain and productive cough yielding thick, yellowish sputum. The symptoms developed three days ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient consumes 2-3 glasses of alcohol and one pack of cigarettes daily. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 167/90 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. Radiographic imaging is demonstrated below. Which of the following structures is most obscured as a result of this patient’s disease process?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has a left parapneumonic effusion, obscuring the left cardiac border. The inferior portions of the left cardiac border are formed by the left ventricle.  

Key anatomical landmarks seen on chest x-rays are as follows:



Option Analysis

✅ Left ventricle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aortic knob:
Incorrect: A left upper lobe consolidation or mass can obscure the aortic knob. However, this patient has a parapneumonic effusion in the dependent portions of the left lung field, which obscures the inferior left cardiac border formed by the left ventricle.
❌ Carina:
Incorrect: The carina refers to the anatomic location where the trachea branches into the left and right mainstem bronchi. The carina is not obscured by this patient’s left parapneumonic effusion.
❌ Right diaphragm:
Incorrect: While there is mild blunting of the right costophrenic angle, the right diaphragm is overall unremarkable. In contrast, the patient has a large left parapneumonic effusion that is obscuring the inferior portions of the left cardiac border.
❌ Left atrium:
Incorrect: A left upper lobe consolidation or mass can obscure the left atrium. However, this patient has a parapneumonic effusion in the dependent portions of the left lung field. This pathology obscures the inferior left cardiac border, which is formed by the left ventricle.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being pulled out of a frozen lake. The family reports the patient was fishing when he suddenly fell through the ice; he was extricated 10 minutes later. The patient has a past medical history of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and hypertension. His temperature is 34°C (93.2°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 110/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Physical examination shows a male patient who is shivering, appears pale, and is cool to the touch. The patient can speak one- to two-word sentences at a time, but his history is limited by a persistent non-productive cough and altered mental status. The patient is subsequently intubated for airway protection and admitted to the intensive care unit on mechanical ventilation. A chest x-ray and laboratory results are demonstrated below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood Gases, Serum 
pH  7.49 
 PCO2  24 mmHg 
 PO2  53 mm Hg 
 Cardiac Enzymes, Serum 
 Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP)  <100 ng/dL (N = <100) 
 Troponin  <.03 ng/dL 
Which of the following is a recommended treatment strategy for the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is likely suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) given his recent submersion injury, bilateral opacities on chest x-ray, normal brain natriuretic peptide, and PO2:FiO2 ratio < 300. In patients with ARDS, the ideal ventilator settings should be titrated to low, weight-based tidal volumes and plateau pressures ≤30 cm H2O. High tidal volumes and high plateau pressures can result in an increased risk of barotrauma, due to the stress of positive pressure mechanical ventilation on acutely damaged alveolar membranes.  

In general, the management of ARDS is supportive, with goal-directed treatment towards the underlying cause. Other interventions that have demonstrated a morbidity/mortality benefit include proning, paralytics, and conservative fluid management. Despite these interventions, ARDS continues to carry a mortality rate of greater than 50%, with ventilator-associated pneumonia being the leading cause of complications, in addition to barotrauma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Glucocorticoids :
Incorrect: Steroids have been studied for use in patients with ARDS, with inconclusive results thus far. Steroids are generally only recommended in the setting of refractory septic shock unresponsive to standard therapies or in patients with eosinophilic pneumonia.  
❌ Nitric oxide:
Incorrect: Although inhaled nitric oxide has been shown to improve the hypoxemia associated with ARDS, it is not a first-line treatment. Additionally, it has not shown a mortality benefit, and it is associated with a risk of renal impairment.   
✅ Low tidal volume ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Whole blood transfusion :
Incorrect: Although transfusion therapy was initially thought to increase delivery of oxygen in these hypoxemic patients, studies have shown inconsistent results. Patients with ARDS should only have blood transfusions if their hemoglobin falls to a level less than 7 mg/dL.  
❌ Inotropic therapy:
Incorrect: Inotropes, such as norepinephrine, were postulated to augment increased oxygen delivery to tissues in these hypoxemic patients; however, studies have demonstrated that ARDS patients with a normal ejection fraction do not benefit from inotropic therapy.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient states the pain started a few hours ago, and he also feels nauseous and sweaty. He notes that the pain is worse when he lies flat. He has had similar chest discomfort in the past, frequently occurring after eating dinner. The patient has not experienced worsening pain with exertion. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 2-3 beers daily. Past medical history includes obesity, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s father passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 52. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 166/100 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain suggestive of gastrointestinal reflux; however, given his multiple risks for acute coronary syndrome (ACS), ACS must be ruled out. All patients with a chief complaint of chest pain should have an electrocardiogram (ECG) obtained as soon as they are deemed clinically stable.

The acute management of adult chest pain follows a stepwise approach. First, patients should be evaluated for stability, protection of the airway, and mental status. Patients should immediately receive any necessary interventions to stabilize their airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients deemed unstable should then be assessed for life-threatening causes of chest pain, including myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, pericardial tamponade, tension pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and Boerhaave syndrome.

Stable patients should be placed on continuous telemetry with pulse oximetry and have IV access established. A focused history, physical examination, and electrocardiogram (ECG) should be performed. The first step in assessing an ECG is to evaluate for the presence of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Once ruled out, other findings suggestive of cardiac ischemia should be assessed, including ST depressions or T-wave changes (e.g. inversions).

Following these initial steps, patients should be triaged appropriately for further workup of their chest pain–ruling out life-threatening etiologies before anchoring on benign causes such as gastrointestinal reflux.


Option Analysis

✅ Obtain an electrocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administer aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is indicated in the management of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). While this patient carries risk factors for this condition, an electrocardiogram should be obtained first to evaluate for evidence of ischemia.
❌ Administer omeprazole:
Incorrect: This patient presents with non-exertional chest pain associated with eating, which is not suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However, an electrocardiogram should be obtained first to evaluate for evidence of ischemia before anchoring on to a gastrointestinal etiology.
❌ Obtain a chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Chest radiography is often indicated in the management of chest pain; however, an electrocardiogram should be obtained first to evaluate for evidence of ischemia.
❌ Apply supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal oxygen saturation on room air; thus supplemental O2 is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is brought to a rural emergency department by paramedics due to tonic-clonic seizure activity. The patient is administered multiple doses of lorazepam and levetiracetam over the course of 10 minutes, which fail to terminate the seizure. A decision is made to perform rapid sequence intubation and initiate intravenous propofol. A post-intubation chest x-ray is obtained and shown below. The hospital does not have an on-call radiologist so the image is sent to a teleradiology service for formal interpretation. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Perform needle decompression at the right midaxillary line
Advance enteric tube until side port is below the diaphragm
Await final report from teleradiology service

questions.solution:
This patient undergoes endotracheal intubation. A chest x-ray is subsequently obtained, revealing that the endotracheal tube tip is located in the right mainstem bronchus. In contrast, the tip of a properly positioned tube should terminate approximately 3-5 cm above the carina to ensure that both lungs are ventilated. As such, this tube should be retracted.  

It is important for clinicians to be able to personally interpret chest x-rays, as a radiologist may not always be available. When reviewing chest x-rays, it is important to follow a systematic approach to minimize the risk of overlooking pathological findings. For each chest x-ray, the following structures and regions need to be reviewed:  



Option Analysis

❌ Perform needle decompression at the right midaxillary line:
Incorrect: A tension pneumothorax can be treated with needle decompression. On chest x-ray, this condition presents as a visible visceral pleural edge and an absence of distal lung markings, as well as contralateral deviation of the mediastinum. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings are more consistent with right mainstem intubation and hyperinflation of the right lung. 
✅ Retract the endotracheal tube:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Advance enteric tube until side port is below the diaphragm:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest x-ray shows an endotracheal tube and EKG leads. There is no enteric tube.
❌ Initiate intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy:
Incorrect: Ampicillin-sulbactam can be used to treat aspiration pneumonia, which can develop in patients with seizure activity. However, this patient’s chest x-ray demonstrates right mainstem intubation, which can lead to hypoxemia, barotrauma of the right lung, and atelectasis of the left lung. Addressing this finding should take precedence over starting antibiotic therapy.  
❌ Await final report from teleradiology service:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest x-ray demonstrates right mainstem intubation, which can lead to hypoxemia, barotrauma of the right lung, and atelectasis of the left lung. The endotracheal tube should be immediately retracted to ensure both lungs are ventilated. It would be inappropriate to wait for the final report from teleradiology before intervening.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is currently in the medical intensive care unit secondary to sepsis from bacterial pneumonia. The patient's current vital signs are temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), respirations are 22/minute, pulse is 111/minute, and blood pressure is 85/70 mmHg. The patient receives intravenous antibiotic therapy and 30cc/kg of normal saline without significant blood pressure changes. A decision is made to obtain central venous access via the right internal jugular vein for administration of norepinephrine.  Which of the following anatomical structures is at risk of injury during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Central venous access refers to a procedure in which a catheter is inserted into one of the major veins leading directly to the right heart. The three anatomical sites commonly used to insert central venous catheters include the internal jugular vein, the subclavian vein, and the femoral vein. Indications for central venous access include medication administration (e.g. vasopressors), rapid transfusion of blood products, inadequate intravenous access (unable to obtain access or severely hypovolemic), emergent hemodialysis, and plasmapheresis continuous hemodynamic monitoring.

The sigmoid sinus exits the jugular foramen in the neck and continues in the neck to form the internal jugular vein.  The internal jugular vein travels within the carotid sheath, just lateral to the internal carotid artery, with the vagus nerve sitting between the two vessels.  It joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein at the clavicle level.

Several anatomic landmarks are used to identify the internal jugular vein. The anterior triangle of the neck is bounded inferiorly by the clavicle, medially by the medial head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, and laterally by the lateral head of the sternocleidomastoid. The internal carotid artery is isolated by palpation, which lies medial to the internal jugular vein. The needle is inserted at a 40-degree angle to the skin at the apex of the anterior cervical triangle, aiming towards the ipsilateral nipple. Typically, the procedure is performed under ultrasound guidance.

In the medial neck, the axillary vein continues to form the subclavian vein and joins the internal jugular vein to form the brachiocephalic vein. The surgical landmark for isolating the subclavian vein is 1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle. The needle is advanced beneath the clavicle towards the sternal notch, usually without ultrasound guidance.

Structures at risk of injury during central venous access include the apex of the lung (pneumothorax), internal carotid artery, vagus nerve, and the thoracic duct (with left SC or left IJ approach). Additional complications include hematoma formation, arterial puncture, arrhythmia, air embolism, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.    

Option Analysis

✅ Internal carotid artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid gland:
Incorrect: The thyroid gland lies inferior-medial to the anatomic site where central venous access is obtained via the internal jugular vein. This structure is not at risk of injury during this procedure.  
❌ Aortic outflow tract:
Incorrect: The aortic outflow tract lies within the mediastinum and, in general, is not at risk of injury during this procedure, given access is obtained via the venous system in the neck with catheter placement into the right heart.  
❌ Brachial plexus:
Incorrect: The brachial plexus is a deep structure with a low risk of injury when central access is obtained via the internal jugular vein. A small risk of brachial plexus injury exists when access is attempted via the subclavian approach.  
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Like the thyroid gland, the recurrent laryngeal nerve lies inferomedial to the anatomic site where central venous access is obtained via the internal jugular vein. This structure is not at risk of injury with this procedure.

questions.text: A medication is currently under-review for administration in human clinical trials. The medication has been previously tested in rat models with the following observed changes in hemodynamic properties. Pharmacological data indicates this medication carries beta agonist properties without associated alpha agonism. Which of the following describes an appropriate clinical use of the medication described above?

choices.text: Acute heart failure with cardiogenic shock

questions.solution:
The medication described carries only beta agonist properties and is found to result in a widened pulse pressure, increased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance, and ultimately decreased mean arterial pressure. These findings are consistent with the non-specific beta agonist isoproterenol, which can be used as an inhaled medication for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations due to its agonistic effects on ß2 receptors.    

Isoproterenol is the prototypical non-selective beta agonist and is rarely used in clinical practice due to its hemodynamic effects. By stimulating ß2 receptors, isoproterenol results in bronchodilation and smooth muscle relaxation, causing decreased peripheral resistance and widened pulse pressure with subsequent reflex tachycardia. In concert, the ß1 effects result in an augmented tachycardia and cardiac stimulation.    

Isoproterenol carries little clinical utility in modern medicine but can be used as an adjunct for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations, bronchospasm, refractory high grade AV block, or during evaluation of tachyarrhythmias. Side effects include excess sympathomimetic effects, predominantly arising from the sustained tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acute asthma exacerbation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute heart failure with cardiogenic shock:
Incorrect: Dobutamine is often used in the treatment of cardiogenic shock secondary to decompensated heart failure in an attempt to increase cardiac output. Isoproterenol, a non-selective beta agonist, is not used for this condition.  
❌ Anaphylactic shock:
Incorrect: The medication of choice in acute anaphylaxis or anaphylactic shock is epinephrine. Unlike isoproterenol, epinephrine will result in an increased mean arterial pressure.  
❌ Septic shock:
Incorrect: Isoproterenol is not the first-line treatment for septic shock. Norepinephrine, which increases systemic vascular resistance and mean arterial pressure, is the most appropriate first-line medication for this condition. Unlike isoproterenol, norepinephrine results in a reflex bradycardia.  
❌ Nasal congestion:
Incorrect: Inhaled phenylephrine, a pure alpha agonist, is used for the treatment of nasal congestion. Administration of this medication results in a reflex bradycardia, not tachycardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. Over the past few days, the patient has been having difficulty breathing due to weather changes and COPD flare ups. Past medical history is notable for COPD, for which he takes albuterol as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 166/92 mmHg. There is audible wheezing in the bilateral lung fields. The patient is noted to be using accessory muscles while breathing. The decision is made to perform rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for airway management. Shortly after receiving RSI medications, the patient develops diffuse muscle rigidity and becomes diaphoretic. Repeat vitals reveal a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse of 122/min, and blood pressure of 107/82 mmHg.  Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the medication that most likely precipitated the clinical findings observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of shortness of breath and subsequently undergoes rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for airway management. After administration of RSI medications, the patient develops fever, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction. These findings are consistent with malignant hyperthermia. Of the mechanisms of action listed, only the acetylcholine receptor agonist succinylcholine has been shown to precipitate this condition.  

Despite the widespread use of depolarizing neuromuscular blockers to facilitate endotracheal intubation, these medications are associated with several side effects. These include malignant hyperthermia, hyperkalemia, as well as postoperative myalgias due to muscle fasciculations.    

Depolarizing neuromuscular blockers should be used with caution in patients with hyperkalemia and end-stage renal disease. They should be avoided in patients with burns causing significant tissue damage (due to increased risk of hyperkalemia) or history of malignant hyperthermia. In addition, these medications are contraindicated in those with neurological injury (e.g., cerebral vascular accident, spinal cord injury) or degenerative neuromuscular conditions (e.g., ALS, multiple sclerosis) due to upregulation of acetylcholine receptors and risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Acetylcholine receptor agonist :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Competitive acetylcholine receptor antagonist :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers, such as rocuronium. These medications are not associated with malignant hyperthermia.   
❌ Potentiation of GABAA receptors :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of propofol, which is not associated with malignant hyperthermia. The most common side effect of propofol is hypotension.    
❌ Ryanodine receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This patient developed fevers, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction after undergoing rapid sequence intubation. These findings are concerning for malignant hyperthermia. Dantrolene, which is a ryanodine receptor antagonist, is used to treat malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ NMDA receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of ketamine, which is often used as an induction agent while intubating patients in severe respiratory distress due its secondary bronchodilatory effects. Ketamine is not associated with malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is undergoing an evaluation for respiratory distress in the emergency department. The patient has been experiencing worsening blurry vision, dysphagia, and dyspnea. The patient describes her breathing as shallow, thus prompting her visit to the emergency department. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, respiratory rate is 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 91%. Negative inspiratory force (NIF) is 24 (normal: -80 to -100). Based on these findings, the emergency medicine physician proceeds to intubate the patient using a medication that works by preventing acetylcholine from binding to receptors on the motor end plate, thus inhibiting depolarization. Which of the following is a known adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with respiratory distress in the setting of an unknown neuromuscular disorder. The patient is subsequently intubated using a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, which is associated with antimuscarinic effects including tachycardia.    

In comparison to depolarizing agents, non-depolarizing agents are generally well-tolerated medications. However, these agents are less selective for the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor on the motor end-plate, resulting in associated antagonistic effects on muscarinic receptors.    

Rocuronium and pancuronium are known to antagonize cardiac muscarinic receptors, resulting in tachycardia. In contrast, succinylcholine, a direct muscarinic agonist, results in bradycardia.    

In addition, several medications in this class including tubocurarine and atracurium are known to stimulate histamine release, causing bronchoconstriction, hypotension, and hives.  

Lastly, these medications have a much longer duration of action when compared to depolarizing agents, thus resulting in an increased risk of aspiration if mechanical ventilation is not promptly initiated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Tachycardia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Laryngospasm:
Incorrect: Ketamine, an NMDA receptor antagonist, has a known adverse effect of laryngospasm. This is not a documented side effect of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.   
❌ Fever and muscular rigidity:
Incorrect: Malignant hyperthermia is a known adverse reaction of succinylcholine, which is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that acts as an agonist at acetylcholine receptors. In contrast, malignant hyperthermia is not associated with non-depolarizing agents.   
❌ Hyperkalemia :
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is a known side effect of depolarizing agents such as succinylcholine. This medication should be used with caution in patients with suspected hyperkalemia or end-stage renal disease, as it may precipitate fatal cardiac arrhythmias.   
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect: Bradycardia is a known side effect of depolarizing agents such as succinylcholine, due to its mechanism of action as a strong muscarinic agonist.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever. The patient was in his usual state of health until he returned home from a dialysis session three days ago and developed fevers, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. Past medical history includes end-stage renal disease, hypertension, diabetes, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 86/62 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is obtunded and responds only to painful stimuli. There is purulent drainage from his dialysis graft. The decision is made to perform rapid sequence intubation for airway protection. In addition to giving etomidate, administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has findings concerning sepsis and bacteremia. Given his history of end-stage renal disease, the most appropriate medication to administer for rapid sequence intubation is the non-depolarizing drug rocuronium.  

Neuromuscular blocking medications are used most commonly during intubation, prolonged surgeries, and for the facilitation of mechanical ventilation. Several critical considerations arise when deciding whether to administer a non-depolarizing agent or a depolarizing agent.    

Succinylcholine, the most widely used depolarization agent, carries a risk of inducing malignant hyperthermia and hyperkalemic cardiac arrest. The medication should be used with caution in patients with hyperkalemia and end-stage renal disease. It should be avoided in patients with burns causing significant tissue damage (due to increased risk of hyperkalemia) or history of malignant hyperthermia. In addition, succinylcholine is contraindicated in those with neurological injury (e.g., cerebral vascular accident, spinal cord injury) or degenerative neuromuscular conditions due to upregulation of acetylcholine receptors and risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia. For patients without any of the aforementioned contraindications, succinylcholine is the preferred agent of choice for rapid sequence intubation given its rapid onset and short duration of action.  

In contrast, nondepolarizing medications such as cisatracurium and rocuronium have a much longer half-life and duration of action when compared to succinylcholine. These medications are ideal agents for prolonged surgery or mechanical ventilation synchrony. The specific nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker to use is largely dependent on the desired duration of effect as well as the patient’s hepatic and renal function.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rocuronium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Succinylcholine:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of end-stage renal disease and is at risk of hyperkalemia. Succinylcholine should be avoided in the rapid sequence intubation of this patient due to its ability to precipitate or worsen underlying hyperkalemia.   
❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic used for sedation, not neuromuscular blockade. Administration of propofol with etomidate can produce deep sedation, but will not relax the vocal cords for adequate passage of an endotracheal tube.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: A sedative and neuromuscular blocker should be administered prior to rapid sequence intubation. Etomidate is a sedative commonly used for this purpose. Therefore, a neuromuscular blocker, as opposed to another sedative such as ketamine, should be administered to this patient.   
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen is an antispasmodic agent and is not used for rapid sequence intubation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought into the intensive care unit for septic shock due to malaria. He is currently on mechanical ventilation via an endotracheal tube, and is sedated on propofol. Medications administered include chloroquine, heparin, and propofol. Which of the following is true regarding the volume of distribution (VD) and lipophilicity of these medications?

choices.text: Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic
Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic
Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic

questions.solution:
Lipophilicity affects the volume of distribution of medications. The more hydrophobic (lipophilic) a medication, the more easily it can diffuse through the lipid bilayer of cell membranes and distribute throughout the body, especially in adipose tissue. Medications that are very hydrophobic (lipophilic) tend to have high volumes of distribution. For example, propofol is very lipophilic and its volume of distribution can approach 60 L/kg in adults. This explains why propranolol, unlike many other beta-blockers, can be used to treat essential tremor and performance anxiety – it is much more lipophilic than other beta-blockers and easily diffuses across the blood-brain barrier.  

On the other hand, medications that are very hydrophilic (lipophobic) tend to stay in the bloodstream, as they do not readily cross cell membranes. For example, heparin’s volume of distribution is around 0.1 L/kg in adults.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Chloroquine is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
❌ Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a high VD  are generally hydrophobic (lipophilic), since hydrophobic molecules can easily cross lipid membrane layers and distribute widely throughout tissue. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD  are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Propofol is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
✅ Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit following an opiate overdose requiring intubation. The patient is mechanically ventilated and sedated on a propofol and fentanyl infusion. During rounds, the patient appears increasingly cyanotic. The patient has a history of alcoholism and opiate use disorder and does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate 115/min, blood pressure 136/68 mmHg, respiratory rate 10/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 93% on 100% FIO<sub>2</sub>. The patient is not over-breathing the ventilator. Bilateral breath sounds are present and cardiac examination is within normal limits. The patient has evidence of skin cyanosis. Stat blood gas results are obtained, which show pH 7.27 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 50. A chest x-ray demonstrates that the endotracheal tube is 2 cm above the carina. Which of the following should be assessed next to help determine the cause of cyanosis and respiratory acidosis in this patient?

choices.text: Endotracheal tube placement via direct laryngoscopy

questions.solution:
This patient is intubated and sedated following respiratory failure secondary to opiate overdose. The patient has evidence of cyanosis on examination with confirmed proper placement of the endotracheal tube, and ABG results demonstrate respiratory acidosis. Given this clinical setting, iatrogenic causes of respiratory acidosis secondary to ventilation should be considered, such as low tidal volumes, low respiratory rate, and equipment failure. A fault in any one of these settings may result in hypercapnia and subsequent acidosis. This patient’s respiratory rate is most likely set too low given his RR of 10 breaths/min and likely resultant respiratory acidosis. 

Many conditions fall can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and parenchymal pulmonary etiologies; however, the presenting symptoms will be similar. Patients with respiratory acidosis may present with cyanosis, a decreased respiratory rate, or shortness of breath. Depending on the degree of hypercapnia, patients may also develop altered mental status and lethargy. Specific etiologies and appropriate treatments can be suggested by the clinical scenario–e.g., ventilated patients may need ventilator settings adjusted. Whereas patients with a focal neurologic deficit should have brain imaging to rule out CNS pathology (e.g., ICH).    

Option Analysis

✅ Ventilator settings:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rate of fentanyl infusion:
Incorrect: This patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a set respiratory rate. The rate of fentanyl infusion will not affect the respiratory parameters and cause a low respiratory rate of 10 breaths/min which is most likely the cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient. 
❌ Ocular examination:
Incorrect: An ocular examination is unlikely to provide useful information regarding the cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient who is sedated on propofol and fentanyl and has a low respiratory rate and raspatory acidosis. 
❌ Reflexes:
Incorrect: Reflexes would not add additional information for this patient who is intubated and sedated with new cyanosis, respiratory acidosis, and a low respiratory rate. 
❌ Endotracheal tube placement via direct laryngoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient has an endotracheal tube that is appropriately positioned on chest x-ray. Direct laryngoscopy is not necessary now and would not add more information. This patient should have the ventilatory settings checked and likely have the respiratory rate increased.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe angioedema. Several attempts are made to intubate without success, and the decision is made to perform an emergent cricothyroidotomy. After identifying the appropriate anatomic landmarks and prepping the patient with betadine, the physician begins the procedure by making a midline vertical incision below the thyroid cartilage and above the cricoid cartilage. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury if the vertical incision is extended too far inferiorly?
questions.solution:
The thyroid ima artery is an uncommon variant of blood supply to the inferior aspect of the thyroid gland. It arises from the brachiocephalic trunk, right common carotid artery, or aortic arch. It ascends on the anterior surface of the trachea to the isthmus of the thyroid gland and supplies blood to the thyroid gland, trachea, parathyroid glands, and thymus.

Due to its location and course, it can be injured during head and neck procedures such as cricothyroidotomy, thyroidectomy, or tracheostomy. When injured, it can be a source of brisk and potentially difficult to control bleeding as the cut vessel often retracts below the manubrium.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid ima artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is at risk of injury if the incision is extended too far laterally, not inferiorly. This vessel is at risk of injury by placing a central venous catheter in the neck.  
❌ Thyroid lobe:
Incorrect: The lobes of the thyroid lie lateral to the trachea and are at risk of injury if an incision is extended too far laterally.  
❌ Vocal cords:
Incorrect: The vocal cords are at risk of injury if the incision is extended too far superiorly, not inferiorly.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The internal jugular veins, like the internal carotid arteries, lie lateral to the trachea and are at risk of injury should an incision be extended too far laterally.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a history of sickle cell disease is admitted for transfusion of three units of packed red blood cells. Approximately two hours post-transfusion, she begins experiencing shortness of breath and orthopnea. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate is 102/min, blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals rales halfway up the bilateral lung fields, jugular venous distension, and 3+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Chest X-ray is significant for an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following should be done next to help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of fluid overload and chest X-ray findings of an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. In the context of a recent blood transfusion, this clinical presentation is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis. It can evaluate cardiac function and volume status.

TACO typically occurs when the volume of transfused blood products overloads the patient's cardiovascular system, leading to fluid overload and pulmonary edema. Risk factors include a history of heart failure or renal insufficiency. A diagnosis of TACO can be made in patients with signs and symptoms suggestive of volume overload following a blood transfusion with findings of an elevated BNP, cardiogenic pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (Kerley B lines, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, peribronchial cuffing), and signs of left ventricular dysfunction and volume overload on TTE.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Furosemide should improve her symptoms; however, transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is needed for definitive diagnosis.  
❌ Administration of high-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Corticosteroids do not address the fluid overload and cardiac strain that occurs in patients with TACO. Therefore, administration of high dose corticosteroids will not lead to clinical improvement, nor will it help determine the underlying condition.  
❌ CT angiography of the chest:
Incorrect: CT angiography is indicated for patients with suspected pulmonary embolism. This patient's presentation and signs of fluid overload and an enlarged cardiac silhouette following a transfusion is more suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO); this requires transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Electrocardiogram (ECG):
Incorrect: An electrocardiogram (ECG) should be performed to rule out cardiac ischemia. However, this patient's clinical presentation, including hypertension, rales, peripheral edema, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette, points to transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) rather than a primary cardiac event. Transthoracic echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of chronic anemia is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath and chest tightness that developed 30 minutes after receiving a packed red blood cell transfusion. His past medical history includes hypertension and chronic kidney disease stage 3. His regular medications include lisinopril and amlodipine. On examination, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales at the lung bases and distended jugular veins. Electrocardiogram (ECG) is significant for sinus tachycardia and voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, creatinine of 3.2 mg/dL, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP). Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. An echocardiogram is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic anemia and chronic kidney disease presents with sudden onset respiratory distress, hypertension, signs of volume overload, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) after receiving a blood transfusion. These findings are suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). The best next step in management is to administer IV furosemide.

TACO typically occurs when the volume of transfused blood products overwhelms the patient's cardiovascular system, leading to fluid overload and respiratory distress from pulmonary edema. Patients with underlying conditions like hypertension and chronic kidney disease are at increased risk for developing TACO with blood transfusions.

Treatment includes immediately stopping the blood transfusion if it is still in progress and intravenous furosemide. Furosemide reduces circulating blood volume and pulmonary congestion, which improves respiratory distress and oxygenation. This intervention is critical for managing the patient's acute symptoms and mitigating respiratory compromise. Supportive care, including supplemental oxygen and close monitoring of hemodynamic status, is also indicated.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Although the patient has chronic kidney disease, immediate hemodialysis is not indicated in the absence of severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics, life-threatening electrolyte disturbances, or uremic complications. Initial management should focus on diuretic therapy.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). While severe respiratory distress may require intubation, initial therapy should target fluid overload. Intubation should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial medical management with diuretics or if their respiratory status worsens.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) metoprolol  :
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). IV metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not appropriate in the acute setting. It can reduce the heart rate and blood pressure but would not address the underlying condition of volume overload.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) enalapril:
Incorrect: IV enalapril is used for managing hypertensive emergencies. It is used in the acute management of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) where the main goal of treatment is to reduce excess fluid rapidly with diuretics like furosemide.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital for management of severe pancreatitis diagnosed three days ago. Despite initial treatment, he has worsening respiratory symptoms. Past medical history is significant for chronic alcohol use and 2 prior episodes of pancreatitis. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate is 115/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 92/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 86% on room air, which improves to 90% with 6 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient appears to be in distress and is using accessory muscles to breathe. Physical examination reveals decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, and abdominal tenderness with guarding in the epigastric region and without distension or fluid waves. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields. There is no lower extremity edema. Laboratory tests indicate persistent elevation of amylase and lipase. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following can be used to establish the most likely diagnosis in this patient? 



Image courtesy of STATdx

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of chronic alcohol use, presents with worsening respiratory symptoms in the context of severe pancreatitis. His clinical picture, including marked hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 86% on room air, minimally responsive to supplemental oxygen), respiratory distress, bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields, and diffuse bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray strongly suggests acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300, assessed by arterial blood glass (ABG) analysis and estimated FiO2 in non-intubated patients, is necessary to make the diagnosis of ARDS in this patient.        

ARDS is characterized by rapid onset of severe inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability and alveolar damage. Patients typically present with rapid onset of severe respiratory distress, often following a precipitating event such as sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, or pancreatitis. Clinically, patients exhibit marked hypoxemia, dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis, and use of accessory muscles for breathing. Physical examination is significant for bilateral diffuse crackles on lung auscultation in the absence of signs of volume overload such as pitting lower extremity edema and jugular venous distention. Imaging, including chest x-ray or CT, will show bilateral pulmonary opacities, and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300 in non-intubated patients will be calculated. The diagnosis of ARDS can be made clinically in patients who meet all the criteria listed below.   



Option Analysis

✅ Arterial blood gas analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CT scan of the chest with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A CT scan with IV contrast can provide detailed images of lung pathology but is not necessary for diagnosing ARDS. The diagnosis of ARDS can be made clinically, based on agreed-upon diagnostic criteria that include a PaO2/FiO2 of ≤ 300 in non-intubated patients and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis. 
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram :
Incorrect: For patients with suspected ARDS, it should be determined that respiratory distress is not from cardiac failure or volume overload. In this patient who has no prior history of coronary artery disease or other cardiac dysfunction and has evidence of dehydration on exam, and onset of symptoms within 1 week of severe pancreatitis, ARDS is the likely cause of respiratory distress. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is necessary to make the diagnosis.  
❌ B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level:
Incorrect: BNP testing is useful for distinguishing between cardiac and pulmonary causes of respiratory failure. However, the absence of volume overload in this patient without a history of cardiac dysfunction and the onset of symptoms within 1 week of severe pancreatitis is more indicative of ARDS than other causes of respiratory distress. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is needed to make the diagnosis in this patient and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis. 
❌ Sputum culture:
Incorrect: While a sputum culture can identify causative pathogens in respiratory infections when that is the inciting event of ARDS, it is not necessary to make the diagnosis of ARDS. In the context of severe pancreatitis, ARDS is primarily caused by an inflammatory response in the lungs, often secondary to systemic factors, rather than a direct result of lung infection. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is needed to make the diagnosis of ARDS in this patient and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension is brought to the emergency department for severe shortness of breath. She has been experiencing a worsening cough and fever over the past 5 days. Temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 89/54 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% on 60% FiO2 via a non-rebreather mask. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. There is no jugular venous distension and no lower extremity edema. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Results from the laboratory evaluation are shown below. A bedside echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular systolic function and preserved ejection fraction. Arterial blood gas and FiO2 are used to calculate a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient? 

 Complete Blood Count    
 Hemoglobin (Hb)     12.5 g/dL   
 White Blood Cells (WBC)     17,000/µL   
 Platelets     400,000/µL   
 General Chemistry    
 Sodium     140 mEq/L    
 Potassium     4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride     102 mEq/L    
 CRP     40 mg/L
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of respiratory distress in the setting of 5 days of a worsening cough, fever, hemodynamic instability, hypoxemia, leukocytosis on laboratory evaluation, and diffuse bilateral opacities on chest x-ray, strongly suggests acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to sepsis (likely from a severe pulmonary infection such as pneumonia). The arterial blood gas (ABG) in patients with ARDS typically shows a combination of hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis due to impaired gas exchange and lung mechanics. The expected ABG pattern in ARDS includes a low pH (acidemia) (ie 7.15), low PaO2 (hypoxemia) (ie 58), and elevated PaCO2 (hypercapnia) (ie 48) as seen in answer A. For this patient, low bicarbonate (HCO3-) level (19) suggests a concomitant metabolic acidosis from sepsis due to lactic acid production from tissue hypoperfusion.        

A clinical diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) can be made based on agreed-upon criteria. ARDS can be diagnosed in patients like this one with a clinical insult or new or worsening symptoms within 1 week of presentation, bilateral pulmonary opacities on imaging (not explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules), and respiratory failure evidenced by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300 that is not fully attributable to cardiac failure or fluid overload.        

PaO2/FiO2 is determined based on estimated FiO2 in non-intubated patients and ventilator settings in intubated patients and ABG and is used to stratify patients based on the severity of ARDS. This stratification can then be used to guide management. Patients can be diagnosed with mild (>200 mmHg but ≤300 mmHg), moderate (>100 mmHg but ≤200 mmHg) or severe (≤ 100 mmHg) disease.    

Option Analysis

✅  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.15     58     48     19    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.55   602124:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG pattern indicates primary respiratory alkalosis with hypoxemia, which is more consistent with conditions like pulmonary embolism. In ARDS, patients are expected to have respiratory acidosis, hypercapnia, and metabolic acidosis. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.4 703724:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A normal ABG pattern like this one would not be expected based on this patient's severe symptoms and clinical, imaging and laboratory findings. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.36554530:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG is consistent with respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, more indicative of chronic respiratory conditions. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.44602521:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG pattern is consistent with chronic pulmonary embolism, characterized by hypoxemia, respiratory alkalosis, and compensated metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension is admitted to the intensive care unit for management of pneumonia and subsequent acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was intubated and mechanically ventilated due to worsening hypoxemia. His initial ventilator settings were set to a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight, with a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cm H2O. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), heart rate is 102/min, respiratory rate is set at 12 breaths/min on the ventilator, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on FiO2 of 50%. The patient is put in a prone position. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows pH 7.3, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, PaO2 55 mm Hg, and HCO3- 24 mEq/L. PaO2/FiO2 ratio=110. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Increase positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O
Switch the patient to a supine position

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to pneumonia. Based on PaO2/FiO2 ratio=110 he can be diagnosed with moderate disease. The best step to improve oxygenation in this patient is to increase the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O. The patient's current oxygen saturation (88%) and PaO2 (55 mm Hg) indicate inadequate oxygenation, necessitating adjustments in ventilator settings.        

Increasing PEEP is a key strategy to improve oxygenation in ARDS. It helps to recruit collapsed alveoli, improve functional residual capacity, and reduce intrapulmonary shunting, thereby enhancing oxygenation. A careful increase in PEEP can improve gas exchange without significantly raising the risk of barotrauma.        

For hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mm Hg), increasing PEEP is recommended to improve oxygenation before escalating FiO2, due to the risks associated with oxygen toxicity. Hyperoxia (PaO2 > 90 mm Hg) warrants decreasing FiO2 to avoid similar toxicities. On the ventilation side, if the patient is acidotic (PaCO2 high and pH < 7.25), increasing the respiratory rate (RR) is advised, and as a last resort, increasing tidal volume (Vt) may be considered. Conversely, if PaCO2 is low and pH > 7.45, reducing Vt or RR is recommended, and sedation may be deepened to decrease metabolic demand and respiratory drive. Throughout the management, ensuring lung-protective ventilation to prevent alveolar overdistension is critical. This is assessed by measuring plateau pressure (Pplat) with an inspiratory hold, aiming for a goal Pplat ≤ 30 cm H2O.        

For patients with moderate severity, ARDS-prone positioning and increased levels of PEEP may be used. In addition to ventilator management, all patients with ARDS should receive supportive care, potentially medications like diuretics, and severity should be assessed regularly to determine the need for other measures like neuromuscular agents to induce paralysis and ECMO for severe disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Increase positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Increase FiO2 to 80%:
Incorrect: Escalating FiO2 to 80% is not the first-line approach for moderate hypoxemia in ARDS. High FiO2 levels can increase the risk of oxygen toxicity. The primary strategy should be to optimize PEEP to improve oxygenation while minimizing potential oxygen-related lung injury. 
❌ Increase tidal volume to 8 mL/kg:
Incorrect: Increasing tidal volume to 8 mL/kg is generally avoided in ARDS due to the risk of volutrauma and should only be considered as a last resort for severe refractory hypercapnia, which this patient does not currently exhibit. 
❌ Increase respiratory rate to 16 breaths/min:
Incorrect: Adjusting the respiratory rate is not the first step in addressing hypoxemia in patients with moderate ARDS. It is considered when addressing ventilation issues, particularly hypercapnia. In this patient with ARDS and acceptable PaCO2 levels, the priority is to optimize oxygenation through PEEP adjustments rather than altering respiratory rate. 
❌ Switch the patient to a supine position:
Incorrect: Prone positioning is recommended in moderate ARDS to improve oxygenation as it decreases the amount of weight and compression on the lungs, allowing more air to get to the alveoli, which has already been implemented for this patient. Reverting to supine positioning is contrary to the recommended practice for severe hypoxemia in ARDS and could potentially worsen V/Q mismatch and oxygenation.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man was brought to the emergency department in winter after being found down in an alley. The patient was given naloxone prior to arrival with minimal change in arousal. Initial temperature is 35.0°C (95.0°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 9/min, blood pressure is 115/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on 6L nasal cannula. The patient is unresponsive to verbal or painful stimuli. Track marks are noted in the upper and lower extremities. There are pinpoint pupils bilaterally. The emergency medicine physician decides to intubate the patient using rocuronium and etomidate. During the procedure, the physician is unable to visualize the vocal cords due to copious secretions and an anterior airway. A decision is made to terminate the procedure. Repeat temperature is 33.0°C (91.4°F), pulse is 20/min, respirations are 7/min, blood pressure is 55/22 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 56% on 6L nasal cannula. Administration of which of the following medications is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is obtunded and undergoes unsuccessful rapid sequence intubation with rocuronium and etomidate. The patient’s clinical course is likely to further decline without rapid reversal of his paralysis. The most appropriate medication for this patient is sugammadex, a potent reversal agent for rocuronium.  

Several options exist for the reversal of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade. The overall goals of these interventions are to either directly remove the neuromuscular blocker or increase the concentration of acetylcholine within the synaptic cleft and prevent unwanted side effects.    

If rocuronium is used, sugammadex, a gamma-cyclodextrin, encapsulates and subsequently inactivates this medication. Other measures include administration of a cholinesterase inhibitor along with a muscarinic antagonist to mitigate effects such as increased secretions or bradycardia. Current recommendations prefer the use of neostigmine along with atropine or glycopyrrolate; however, edrophonium may also be used if neostigmine is unavailable.   

Option Analysis

✅ Sugammadex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is a direct muscarinic antagonist and has a similar mechanism of action as non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., atracurium, rocuronium). Administration of this medication is unlikely to yield a clinical benefit.   
❌ Physostigmine :
Incorrect: Physostigmine is a reversible inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase, which ultimately increases the amount of acetylcholine within the synaptic cleft. While this medication may assist in reversing this patient’s paralysis, sugammadex would be more effective in achieving this objective.   
❌ Dantrolene:
Incorrect: Dantrolene is a ryanodine receptor antagonist. It  is used in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia, which presents with hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction. This patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with those of malignant hyperthermia.   
❌ Flumazenil :
Incorrect: Flumazenil is the medication used to treat benzodiazepine toxicity and functions by working as a GABA receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is undergoing a red blood cell transfusion. Thirty minutes into the transfusion, he suddenly develops dyspnea, cough, and chest tightness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, he appears anxious and tachypneic. There is no rash or urticaria. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral rales without wheezing. There is no lower extremity edema. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and provide respiratory support
Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone
Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) furosemide
Continue the blood transfusion and administer intramuscular (IM) epinephrine
Continue the blood transfusion and initiate intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient exhibits sudden onset dyspnea, cough, chest tightness, hypotension, and hypoxemia during a blood transfusion and most likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). TRALI is a life-threatening complication of blood transfusions that is characterized by acute respiratory distress and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. It typically occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. Management of TRALI involves immediate cessation of the blood transfusion and immediate airway and hemodynamic stabilization.

TRALI is caused by donor antibodies reacting against the recipient's leukocytes, leading to capillary leak and pulmonary edema. The first step in management involves stopping the blood transfusion to prevent further exposure to donor antibodies. Next, patients should receive supportive care with oxygen and mechanical ventilation if needed. This condition can rapidly progress to severe hypoxemia and respiratory failure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stop the blood transfusion and provide respiratory support:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). While the transfusion should be stopped, corticosteroids are not generally recommended for treatment of TRALI. The immediate focus should be on providing respiratory support.  
❌ Stop the blood transfusion and administer intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). Stopping the transfusion is appropriate, but administering IV furosemide is not appropriate treatment of TRALI. It is indicated for transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which is characterized by volume overload; whereas TRALI involves noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.  
❌ Continue the blood transfusion and administer intramuscular (IM) epinephrine:
Incorrect: Continuing the transfusion is contraindicated in the context of a suspected transfusion reaction. Epinephrine is used for anaphylactic reactions, not for transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), and continuing the transfusion could worsen the patient’s condition.  
❌ Continue the blood transfusion and initiate intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). Continuing the blood transfusion in the presence of acute respiratory symptoms suggestive of a transfusion reaction is inappropriate. While the symptoms may mimic sepsis, the temporal relation to the transfusion is more suggestive of TRALI, and antibiotics are not indicated.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath, cough, and fever over the past four days. Her condition has worsened in the last few hours. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 39.3°C (101.1°F), heart rate is 118/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 87/57 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on 4L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient is unable to speak in full sentences and is using accessory muscles to breathe. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles. There is no jugular venous distension or lower extremity edema. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral opacities. Blood cultures are drawn and intravenous (IV) broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Which of the following initial ventilator settings is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with features indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), including hypoxemia, bilateral chest X-ray opacities, with no signs of volume overload. ARDS is characterized by rapid onset of severe inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability and alveolar damage. Patients typically present with rapid onset severe respiratory distress, often following a precipitating event such as sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, or pancreatitis. In ARDS management, the aim of mechanical ventilation is to optimize oxygenation and minimize ventilator-induced lung injury. The ideal initial ventilator settings include a low tidal volume (4-8 mL/kg), high initial FiO2 (100%), PEEP of 5 cm H2O, and respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min.         

Initial ventilation settings should start with a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight, within the 4-8 mL/kg range recommended for ARDS. This strategy is employed to reduce the risk of alveolar overdistension and subsequent barotrauma. The FiO2 is initially set to 100% to counter severe hypoxemia quickly, and then it is carefully reduced based on arterial blood gas results, to prevent oxygen toxicity. Setting the Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) at 5 cm H2O helps maintain alveolar patency at the end of expiration, enhancing oxygenation without causing overdistension or barotrauma. Monitoring and maintaining the plateau pressure below 30 cm H2O is also critical to avoid overdistension of the alveoli. Additionally, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min is chosen to facilitate permissive hypercapnia, a tactic that allows higher CO2 levels as a trade-off for lower ventilatory pressures and volumes, thereby reducing the risk of lung injury.   

Option Analysis

✅  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     6     100     5     12    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     12   100    1020:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A tidal volume of 12 mL/kg is significantly higher than the recommended range of 4-8 mL/kg for ARDS, risking ventilator-induced lung injury. Additionally, a high respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min can lead to alveolar overdistension and does not align with the concept of permissive hypercapnia, which is often employed in ARDS management. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     8   60 5    20:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). An FiO2 at 60% may be insufficient for severe hypoxemia, and the initial strategy in ARDS typically starts with 100% FiO2, which is then titrated down based on arterial blood gas results. Additionally, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min may not permit permissive hypercapnia, potentially leading to overventilation. 
❌  Tidal Volume (mL/kg of predicted body weight)     FiO2 (%)     Positive end-expiratory pressure (cm H2O)     Respiratory Rate (breaths/min)     44015 12    :
